results.description:
Interact with your peers in a monthly morning breakfast meetup. At this monthly breakfast get-together techies, developers, designers, and entrepreneurs share learn from their peers through show and tell / show-case style presentations. And yes, this is free! Thank our sponsors when you see them :)

Agenda for Boston TechBreakfast: 8:00 - 8:15 - Get yer Bagels & Coffee and chit-chat
8:15 - 8:20 - Introductions, Sponsors, Announcements
8:20 - ~9:30 - Showcases and Shout-Outs!


Linute: - Andi Muskaj Wizio Inc: wizio.co - Chris Canal GemShelf: - Colin Stack AI - Daniel Heyman ~9:30 - end - Final "Shout Outs" & Last Words Boston TechBreakfast Sponsors: Colliers International - Colliers International is a leader in global real estate, offering comprehensive services to investors, property owners, tenants and developers around the world. DLA Piper (Boston) - DLA Piper is a global business law firm that provides corporate, IP, capital raising and other legal advice to technology startups and high growth businesses. DonQuiSoft - Smart. Mobile. Solutions. Expedient - Expedient, a national leading provider of cloud computing, managed services and colocation. Fairfax County EDA - Fairfax County, the heart of the Washington, D.C., economy and the perfect place for your business. GSN GAMES - Sponsored by GSN Games, one of the top-ranked & highest grossing mobile and web game companies in the U.S. Hired Inc. - Hired believes finding a career should be transparent and unbiased; open the floodgates to 2000+ top companies by making a profile at any time. MaxPoint - MaxPoint drives sales and boosts awareness for brands, retailers, and agencies by combining hyperlocal advertising precision with local, regional, and national advertising reach. Millennial Media - Millennial Media is the leading independent audience platform in digital advertising. Northeastern University - Northeastern University, the leader in experiential education, is a top-50 ranked national research institution with a global network of more than 3,000 corporate partners and more than 200,000 alumni around the world. SmartBooks - SmartBooks acts as an outsourced bookkeeping and accounting department for small to mid-size businesses, providing them with a team of accountants (bookkeeper and controller) as well as software integration to automate data entry and reporting; providing better, faster, and more affordable bookkeeping and accounting. Contact us if you'd like to sponsor!

Venue: MICROSOFT NEW ENGLAND RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT (NERD) CENTER - CAMBRIDGE

Microsoft is hosting us in their amazing New England Research & Development (NERD) Center in Cambridge, MA

Note: This is a secured facility, so you will be asked to show ID and sign in when entering the building


https://encrypted.google.com/maps/vt/data=VLHX1wd2Cgu8wR6jwyh-km8JBWAkEzU4,zb_Cdw19T9yJXeJsRbZGs7H7WYfgiY_Zi7FO59UjQP_g7KnP5SYI34q1i_ngIz9xlEtMP6W672LT9npLvAdhI-dXfyeCF4NVKrnIIj0YxIuePleYhZAGxRhziM8OkmNtyCU&w=182&h=160 View Larger Map

For more directions, check out the Microsoft NERD site here.

  Parking & Transportation
Parking

Microsoft's building has a parking garage in the basement, but there is a cost. Memorial Drive has free parking, but the spaces in front of NERD have a 1 hour limit. Other area streets have metered parking.

Public Transportation

The location is extremely convenient to the MBTA, a 5 minute walk from the Kendall Square MBTA station on the Red Line.

Consent to Recording and Photography By attending this event, you consent to having yourself and/or your presentation video recorded and/or photographed by the TechBreakfast organizers and/or anyone else attending. TechBreakfast retains all rights and ownership to video it produces, and attendees retain the rights to any video or photos they take on their own. You acknowledge that TechBreakfast and/or the attendees can do anything they like with this video and/or photos without your prior consent. Want to present at a showcase? Have something you've been working on that you'd like some feedback on? Have something that you'd like to share? Have a kernel of an idea that you'd like some thoughts on developing further? Just submit your information at http://j.mp/techbreakfast-present and indicate where you'd like to present, and if there's a fit, we'll get you on board! Come to an upcoming event so we can meet up first. If this one is filled up, don't despair - we want you at our next one! Sign up for that one too. Find more events at:

web: techbreakfast.co Facebook: facebook.com/techbreakfast Twitter: @techbreakfast and #techbreakfast YouTube: youtube.com/tekbreakfast LinkedIn: linkedin.com/company/techbreakfast If this event is full and there's a wait list, don't worry! Our wait lists regularly clear out as we get no-shows and last minute cancels. Just sign up if you plan to come! See you all there! Organized and Operated By

results.description:
You will find the Boat Launch entrance and parking lot across the road from 353 Harvard Road, Stow.

Delaney Pond lies at the center of the property, providing an important habitat for otters and a variety of fish and bird species and also provides a unique opportunity for canoeing, fishing and wildlife viewing.

Our hikes meet Tuesdays at 10a at various hiking trails in the metrowest area. The hikes are suited for caregivers who carry their children (usually 2y/o and under) and for young children who walk/run. No stroller hikes unless specified in the details of the hike. Please dress appropriately for the weather and terrain with layers, appropriate footwear and water.

Questions? Or to get more information on the weekly hikes please email...

[masked]

See you there!

Emily
results.name: Hike with the kids at Delaney Conservation Land

results.description:
Bring your little ones and join us for a fun filled storytime! Today our wonderful storyteller's will be reading the hilarious "Happy Birthday Cupcake" by Terry Border. Afterwards, there will be a fun coloring and crafting activity!

See you there!

"What's a cupcake to do when she needs to plan her birthday party? In this hilarious, kid-friendly homage to food and birthdays, Cupcake runs through tons of ideas while her best friend, Blueberry Muffin, finds reasons why they won't work: Soup gets seasick; Donut melts in the sun; someome might get squashed during musical chairs; and Cupcake is not very good at limbo (her icing might get sliced off!). Just as Cupcake is ready to crumble, Blueberry Muffin has one last idea that just might save the day."
results.how_to_find_us: In the childrens department right near the stage

results.description:
Meet me at Diesel Cafe in Davis Square for some midday productivity.

If it's a large group, look for us at the big table in the back. (If it's only a small group of 2 or 3, we might be up front by the windows :-)

Note: you do have to pay for the internet at Diesel ($4.95/hour, $7.95/day) or if you happen to be a Comcast customer, you can also access Xfinity from here.

Also... please do only rsvp 'yes' if you really plan to come so I'm not waiting for you and saving a seat unnecessarily. If your plans change - no worries but please change the rsvp at the site on Meetup. Thanks!
results.how_to_find_us: Will probably be at the big center table in the back
results.name: Tuesday Midday Worktime at Diesel in Davis Square

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.
results.how_to_find_us: Clarendon street entrance. Ask the desk attendant for directions to room.
results.name: Attend a free meeting as a guest and consider joining!

group.name: Boston Public Speaking: Copley Square Toastmasters

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Free DVD screening of "Loving the Silent Tears" 
at three (3) locations in Worcester, Massachusetts

2) Sunday, August 23 from 2-4 pm

Reserve at the Chandler Loving Hut

http://lovinghut.us/worcester 

3) Tuesday, September 1st from 1:00 pm - 3 pm at

Worcester, MA

About the work of art:  May everyone find her or his own peace.  
This is an artistic representation of spiritual harmony among human beings through fundamental inner spiritual transformation and a renewal of nonviolent living.

English language DVD with artistic renditions (music, kinetics) in various human languages... basic is in English 
"Loving the Silent Tears" is a musical journey of the spirit that traverses the seas and continents in a timeless search for inner peace. An unprecedented musical experience, the show will combine the magic of theatre, the mystical beauty of traditional dances, the soul-stirring realm of poetry -- and more. Travel the globe through 16 countries, represented by a dazzling array of ancient and modern music styles, songs sung in many languages, vibrant choreography across the cultures, and of course, a diverse star-filled cast. 

While the story line is in English, songs and some lines from various European and Asian languages will be quite evident. Internationals will love this event. 

To get the invitation, register through this site. There will be vegan food, and you'll need to pass a security guard who will have your first and last names on a list of attendees. You will need to match your printed ticket with that list of names. 

See more at: http://silenttearsmusical.com/#sthash.QYMPBwpv.dpuf 
Go HERE to download 1-5 special reports on the musical. 
http://silenttearsmusical.com/

Allison Joyal was interviewed on Vegan Nation (WCUW.org) about the May 30 screening event in Boston:

http://www.wcuw.org/vegannation/V.N.05.15.15.LovingTheSilentTears.mp3

Note: Same day cancellations will be counted as a no show.

The Seasons 52 menu is seasonally-inspired with the fresh appeal of the farmer’s market. It represents a unique blend of art and science, with creative offerings designed to excite and surprise the palate. We feature dining choices that are thoughtfully prepared and in appropriate portion sizes. So our guests feel the freedom to indulge in a complete dining experience, including our custom flatbreads and signature mini-indulgence desserts, while still feeling good about themselves and their dining choices.

We use natural cooking techniques such as wood-fire grilling, brick-oven cooking and caramelizing vegetables to let the natural flavors shine through. And we execute precision with seasoning, and oil with control and care to ensure just the right amount is used to bring out the great flavor profiles. An added benefit to this style is that our menu items are naturally lower in calories. The result is great tasting, highly satisfying food that just so happens to be good for you!
results.name: Seasons 52 Burlington Dinner and Drinks @ 5:30 pm

results.description:
Level - Middle intermediates (currently playing volleyball regularly, understands and follows basic rules, able to execute basic pass, set and hit skills, and has good fitness).

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

DIRECTIONS

Carson Beach (limited free parking available), William Day Blvd, South Boston, http://www.bostonharborwalk.com...­

The net is blue. There are 2 parking lots (one on each side of beach house). Park in the southern lot (closer to State Police barracks) (or the one on the right side of the beach house as you look at the ocean). You will be able to see me and the net from there.

results.description:
6:00 PM - Network over beer

6:30-8:30PM - Hands-on Machine Learning workshop with Scikit with Lukas Biewald, Founder and CEO of CrowdFlower 

Abstract: 

Machine learning is rapidly becoming prevalent in products we use every day.  Scikit learn is a fantastic toolkit to get started to make real world models in Python.  It powerful and easy to deploy.  Lukas will cover the basic types of machine learning techniques, provide example of real world application and towards the end of the session  participants can build some models together! 

About Lukas Biewald: 

Lukas Biewald is the founder and CEO of CrowdFlower. Founded in 2009, CrowdFlower is a data enrichment platform that taps into an on-demand to workforce to help companies collect, clean and label data to make it more useful. For more information about the speaker, please visit his Linkedin profile.
results.name: Hands-on Machine Learning workshop with Scikit Learn

results.description:
Who wants to get fit for FREE?

Healthy, Fit & Fun promotes exercise and good health in a fun, group setting. People of all ages and abilities are encouraged to come get fit and make new friends while enjoying the beauty of the Esplanade. The Esplanade Association partners with organizations around Boston to offer a diverse array of expert-led fitness classes. All classes are free and open to the public. Registration is required to participate you may pre- register at the event.

Fusing Latin rhythms and easy to follow moves, nothing is more fun and healthy than a high energy Zumba workout. Routines feature interval training sessions where fast and slow rhythms are combined with resistance training. Come get your groove on and break a sweat on the Esplanade. Classes begin 7/14 Classes sponsored by Healthworks. Refreshments provided by Zico and CLIF.

By pre-registering you will receive email updates with any class changes or cancellations.
Cross Posted- http://www.meetup.com/Free-And-Cheap-Things-in-Boston/events/223809095/

Help to support their free public programming - make a donation.

results.description:
Creating Mobile Apps: Native, Hybrid, or Cross Platform Framework?

If you want to create a mobile app targeting the two biggest platforms (iOS and Android), there are choices to make about which development technique to use. This course is aiming to help you make the correct choice by giving an overview and explanation of the three possibilities, and the pros and cons of each in different scenarios.

by Roland Guijt

We will Start with a quick introduction, then dive into specific chapters on Native, Hybrid, and Cross Platform development, Roland dose a great job and dives into each with simple uncomplicated demo's and reviews the pro's and con's of various methods.

results.description:
Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Do you often get stuck in conversations? Not know how to approach people at networking events?


Join Socializing for Justice for a  fast-paced, fun & interactive ProfDev (professional development training) on the Art of the Schmooze on Tuesday, September 1, 6:00 - 8:30 PM. 

Fee: $10 advance/$20 door is split with the trainer.
Limited space - register ahead of time: www.sojust.org
Credit cards accepted online. Cash only at the door (if space available).
Newcomers always welcomed!

 *This is a fragrance-free event. Please do not wear fragrances (scented lotions,  perfumes, etc.) or smoke just prior to attending. Thank you.*

Art of the Schmooze
Forming and cultivating relationships is at the heart of any successful fundraising campaign, volunteer drive, committee effort or community building activity. This training will give you the confidence to pursue your personal and professional goals - from the importance of shaking hands and making eye contact, to tips on the best opening line and how to exit a conversation gracefully. An amazing side benefit is that you'll learn how to create a welcoming community space by keeping an eye out for outliers, considering yourself a host instead of a guest and knowing how to compliment someone without "othering" them.

 

ABOUT OUR PRESENTER 
Robbie Samuels has extensive community organizing, events logistics and fundraising experience. He offers capacity-building trainings and consultation to non-profit boards, development professionals and grassroots organizers. In 2006 he co-founded Socializing for Justice to build a cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community and network in Boston based on the philosophies of abundance and radical inclusion. In 2011, in recognition of his social justice work, Boston City Council named his birthday, September 16, "Robbie Samuels Day". Learn more about his  most requested trainings: "Art of the Schmooze" and "Fundraising: Getting Past the Fear of Asking" at www.robbiesamuels.com. Get connected via LinkedIn and Facebook.

Check out his testimonials - including this one: "Robbie's Art of the Schmooze training totally blew me away. First of all, it must be said-- Robbie is VERY FUNNY. In fact, the workshop felt almost more like a comedy show than a skill-building workshop. It was awesome. Apart from being highly engaging, Robbie was also insightful, informative and wonderfully practical. As someone who often has trouble getting out of dead conversations, I felt like I came out of the workshop with concrete strategies for how to wrap up and end a conversation BEFORE it dies. On the flip side, Robbie also has a number of great stock comments/questions to help keep conversations from prematurely dying. Now, I consider myself an extrovert but it is still extremely helpful to get such a clear explanation of what kinds of questions help deepen connections, and which kinds of questions one should avoid. From handshakes, to body stances, to where to keep your business cards, Robbie knows the ins and outs of how to make connections and keep them. I got so much out of this workshop. I only wish I could sit through it again (and again and again...)." ~Beck Epstein

SCHEDULE
6:00-6:30 Socializing -  bring your own dinner
 6:30-8:30 Training and Q&A

*  DIRECTIONS - The NonProfit Center is located one block from South Station at 89 South Street. The Center is physically accessible through the main lobby.


_________________________________________________________ 
Socializing for Justice - www.sojust.org
Since 2006, we've been building this great sandbox where we can bring progressives of all stripes together and try out new ideas in this "Movement Moment". Spaces like this are crucial as we start to reframe and build new visions for our movement(s).

SoJust hosts events that draw progressives of all stripes that share common values but may work on different issues. We host monthly socials that allow for the possibility of cross-issue connections and run a monthly ProfDev Series, hosted by The NonProfit Center*, which provides access to affordable professional development to increase our individual capacity for movement building.

With 2700 members and nearly 9 years of creating a diverse cross-issue community in Boston (200 events!), Socializing for Justice is the best place to find the great people, organizations and community you're looking for while putting the SOCIAL back in social justice.

YES, WE MEAN YOU. We've got members of all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.
results.name: ProfDev: Art of the Schmooze

results.description:
Amanda W. Florek, Esq. 


                                           Liberty Title 


The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act has handed down many new changes, and now the changes to the HUD-1 and closing process is upon us.  One of our REIA sponsors, Amanda Tiernam, from Liberty Title Services, LLC in Boston will be joining us to explain what it all means and the ways that it changes business for us.  


The HUD-1 settlement statement and Good Faith Estimate forms are going away on August 1. The Truth in Lending Act disclosure is going away as well. In their place will be a new closing disclosure and a new loan estimate. There will be changes to the closing process as well, including a new rule requiring everything to be in place three days prior to closing. And last-minute changes face new hurdles. Learn about the changes in this walk-through   


Join us for our September General Meeting to learn the ins and outs of these changes and take time to meet Amanda to see what he can do to support your business as you move forward!  We will take time to talk about the proper ways to ASSIGN a contract, double close a wholesale, and use or offer private money as it relates to closing and title.

There will be a Q&A Session following the presentation! 


**********************************************************

The Boston Real Estate Investors Association  is open to real estate investors of all experience levels who want to meet and continuously learn from other investors and real estate professionals. Each meeting features knowledgeable speakers to guide members through new and relevant topics relating to the many aspects of Real Estate Investment. Past events have covered Why invest in Real Estate?, Foreclosures, Self-directed IRA's, 1031 Exchanges, and Creative Tax Strategies.

It's an opportunity to network with others who share similar goals & needs, to learn about unique & hot properties, to find ways of obtaining & utilizing different sources of capital, and so much more!
results.name: New HUD1 Closing Regulations - What every Investor MUST KNOW

Let's climb at Central Rock Gym in Watertown! Meet by the cubbies/bench facing the rock wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (JZ) am usually wearing green and have a blue harness and climbing shoes.  We usually climb for ~3 hrs and welcome all skill levels.  If you come late, come find us or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Tuesdays and can help you find the group.

You will need to fill out the rock gym waivers and TAKE their Belay test, if you haven't already.

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
*****Last meetup in our current location!*****

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 8-16 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event. Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 9, Huntington Ave, and is walking distance from the T, near Northeastern and Longwood Medical Areas.

By Subway: Take the Green Line E to Brigham Circle, Tremont Street, cross the tracks. TGIFridays is on the opposite side of the street next to the park.

By Car: If you are driving, parking at the restaurant is ample and free. 
From outside of the city:  Take Rt 9 (boylston) eastbound, go straight onto Huntington and turn right onto Calumet St.  
From inside the city:  Take Rt 9 outbound, and take a left onto Calumet after Brigham & Women's. 
There is parking behind the Stop and Shop.

**PLEASE TAKE NOTICE, the lot has a 90 minute maximum time and according to TGIFriday's staff, they do enforce it.  So you may have to play Musical Parking Spots.... The ALTERNATIVE:  There is a pay lot across Calumet street about a 2 minute walk from the restaurant.

results.description:
Leveraging Social Data in Healthcare

Jared Hawkins (LinkedIn, @Jared_B_Hawkins ) "Using Social Data and Other Non-traditional Digital Data Streams for Public Health Surveillance"  Jared Hawkins is a Research Associate at Boston Children's Hospital / Harvard Medical School - An approach that allows us to identify and analyze specific populations, with the goal of better understanding how their behavior changes over time.  


Clark Freifeld (LinkedIn, @clarkfreifeld) "Digital Disease Detection: Big Data for Public Health. Using Internet media, text processing algorithms, and crowdsourcing for disease outbreak tracking and medical product safety monitoring."  Clark Freifeld is CTO and co-founder of Epidemico and Affiliate Faculty at Boston Children's Hospital. Dr. Freifeld co-created HealthMap, a multilingual, real-time disease outbreak monitoring system and has co-authored over 20 journal articles in the field of health informatics. He   earned his PhD in biomedical engineering from Boston University where his thesis on medical product safety surveillance won the Societal Impact Best Thesis award. He also holds an MS from MIT, and a BS in Computer Science and Mathematics from Yale University.


Morgan Frank (LinkedIn, @mrfrank5790) "Societal well-being, happiness, and Twitter: social data as a thermometer for humanity”. Morgan Frank is a Graduate Research Assistant at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and participated in UVM’s Computational Storylab (they do "blatantly fun" research with social data). He will be discussing several aspects of the project as well as the access and analysis of the data.

results.description:
***This meetup is restricted to people who have attended at least one discussion of the Knapsack meetup group in the last six months. (Most of our meetups count.)***

Each session includes time to: connect with each other, silently reflect and write about our anti-racism work, report on how we're doing regarding our anti-racism work, and receive feedback.  We usually do the reporting and feedback in small groups of 3-4 people.  If you can't stay as late as 9:00, please go ahead and RSVP, just let us know your limitations.

Remember to bring your notebook, if you have one!  (We'll have a few extra for anyone who hasn't come to an accountability session before.)

We have two options for the accountability session each month, hoping that those who want to join us will be able to go to one or the other.  You are welcome to attend both sessions, if you would like to do so. 


For more about our thoughts on these sessions, see "Open discussion to consider monthly accountability sessions."  Note: even if you don't claim to be doing anti-racism work, you can come to the session and see what it is about, as well as consider your own role.  You still need to have met the requirement of having attended one of our discussion meetups within the last six months.


This is also a place where you can learn about and find an accountabilibuddy.

Accessibility Information: Pappenheim Library at Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The sixth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  During regular hours there are usually two tables in the library which limit mobility, but these are normally moved elsewhere during Knapsack events.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.name: September Accountability Session, Option 1 of 2

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a open cards and board game night.  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play whatever there is.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds (Before 6pm) can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog
results.name: Track Tuesday

results.description:
Registration

ENET Member Rate – Free

General Public  – $20.00 (USD)

Student – $10.00 (USD)

Please register at: http://enet.camp7.org/event-2005499/Registration

Pre-registration is preferred, however, walk-ins are always welcome.

Don't forget to meet us at Bertucci's in Waltham for our pre-meeting networking dinner.  This is a self-pay dinner.

5:15 pm AT Bertucci's Restaurant 475 Winter St., Waltham, MA (exit 27B off Route 128)

Meeting Summary:

Successful entrepreneurs have said that fearlessness, resilience, and being true to oneself are three of the most important qualities an entrepreneur must have when starting his/her own business. ENET is assembling a panel of successful founders who made it big in different fields who will tell you what was important in their success. On September 1, 2015, the kick-off meeting to ENET's 25th year, we will hear stories of entrepreneurial challenges, surprises, disappointments, victories and triumphs. We hope you will join us. Learn from the experts: founders who have had the courage and tenacity to step out on their own, and navigate the rough waters of the unknown, and made it big in doing so. If you are thinking of starting your own business, or if you are already a company founder, learn from those who have gone before you. What they have experienced may help you avoid a pitfall or two, and accelerate your own company's progress. Why reinvent the wheel when others willingly share their wisdom? Our meeting begins with an open networking session. A question and answer session follows the presentation, and panelists are available afterwards for responses to individual questions.

Panel: 

Diane Hessan is a successful entrepreneur, marketer and author. She is currently CEO of Startup Institute,  https://www.startupinstitute.com/ which is dedicated to helping people transform their careers and find jobs they love. Via SI’s programs, people gain the skills, mindset and networks to succeed in the exciting startup world. Since its inception only 2 years ago, over 700 students have gone through Startup Institute programs, in Boston, New York, London, Chicago & Berlin.  She is also Chairman of C Space (formerly Communispace),  www.cspace.com/ ,  where she was CEO for 13 years.  A leading customer collaboration agency, Communispace was sold to Omnicom in 2011 and now has over 500 employees, and offices in over a dozen countries. Diane also co-authored the book Customer-Centered Growth: Five Strategies for Building Competitive Advantage,  a Business Week best-seller, now  published in 11 languages.  Diane has received many honors, including  the Most Admired CEO award and Boston Power 50 award from the Boston Business Journal, Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year (National Finalist).  Diane serves on many boards, including Tufts University, Panera, and Horizons for Homeless Children. She received her M.B.A. from Harvard Business School and her B.A. in Economics from Tufts University. She has 2 grown daughters, and is also founder of The Sound Bytes, an a cappella group that sings about business. 

Anthony DiPaolo is CEO, of Work 'N Gear, a workwear and healthcare fashion retailer. http://www.workngear.com Tony is a seasoned entrepreneur and executive with over 30 years of experience in retail, manufacturing, product development, product sourcing and domestic and international sales. His company Work 'N Gear is the largest retail chain in the United States specializing in the work apparel and footwear industry. Work 'N Gear operates more than 45 retail stores throughout the Northeast and Midwest. In 1990, Tony acquired Herman Survivors from Stride Rite Corporation, and raised its sales from $8 million to $50 million before selling the company to Walmart in 2001. In 2002, Tony purchased Work 'N Gear, which was in bankruptcy, raised $40 million in VC investment and with new management focused on the workwear marketplace. In 2011, DiPoalo launched Scrubology -- a new "store-within-a-store" concept that caters to healthcare consumers. In partnership with Sears Holdings Corporation, Scrubology was launched in 39 Sears and Kmart locations across the United States. Committed to his community, with Work 'N Gear, he developed the "Boot Trade" program that each year before the cold of winter hits program provides thousands of pairs of gently worn boots to the homeless in 12 northern states. In telling the ENET audience what was important in his success, Tony will focus on his specialties: Negotiation, financing, leadership and brand repositioning. Tony is a graduate of George Washington University.

Venkat Kolluri is co-founder of Chitika www.chitika.com and has served as President & CEO since the company's inception. Venkat oversees all of Chitika's operations, including it's strategic direction and product planning, as well as corporate development. Previously, Venkat worked at Upromise, leading the Partner Services group in the Database Marketing & Analytics division. Prior to Upromise, he worked at Lycos as the Principal Technologist in the Marketing Services group and spearheaded the development and launch of several innovative advertising and marketing automation products and services across the Lycos Network. Venkat's work has been published in several journals and conferences. Venkat holds a Ph.D. in Information Science from University of Pittsburgh. In 2009, Chitika won the Red Herring award as a Top 100 Global Finalist and in 2010 the DPAC Award as Finalist for Best Mobile Advertising Network Innovation. In 2011, Venkat received from TiE Boston the Crystal Award for a Charter Member who built his company from the ground up.

Moderator:

Robert Adelson, business and tax attorney and partner at the Boston law firm of Engel & Schultz LLP is the Chairman of the IEEE Boston Entrepreneurs’ Network. Rob has been an attorney for over 30 years specializing in business, tax, stock and options, employment, contracts, financings, trademarks and intellectual property. Rob began as an associate at major New York City law firms before returning home to Boston in 1985 where he has since been a partner in small and medium sized firms before joining his present firm in 2004. Rob represents entrepreneurs, start-ups and small companies, independent contractors and employees and executives. Rob is a frequent speaker on business law topics and author of numerous articles published in Boston Business Journal, Mass High Tech and other publications. He has been named among the “Top 20 Boston Startup Lawyers” by ChubbyBrain.com, a website that provides tools for entrepreneurs. Rob has been on the ENET Board since 2002 and Chairman since 2009 and is also a Co-Founder and Board member of the 128 Innovation Capital Group. He holds degrees from Boston University, B.A., summa cum laude, Northwestern University (Chicago), J.D., Law Review, and New York University, LL.M. in Taxation. www.ExecutiveEmploymentAttorney.com
results.name: Giants of the Startup Community, Founders Who Made It Big Tell What's Important

results.description:
Hello community!

I am in a leadership program currently and I have the opportunity to influence people and communities I care about. My friend and I are passionate about creating unity and acceptance within and around the LGBTQ community and empowering all of us to realize our own great potential.

Many of us are:
- hiding ourselves
- not feeling connected to our family
- feeling as though we can"t create our own families
- making up negative stories about our worth
- can't feel connected spiritually
- feeling turmoil within ourselves and witnessing that in our community

You get the picture. How is it possible to be happy inside of all of those filters we live our lives through? How is it possible to find love, peace of mind, and self expression?

The Landmark Forum clears stories like that from our view and we can see ourselves as whole and complete just the way we are. Then we can take actions from that new view and cause breakthroughs in our careers, relationships, and our experience of life. And with that, we can change our community.

That's why my friend and I are hosting a Community Introduction to the Landmark Forum for the LGBTQ community and it will be in Quincy Tuesday September 1st at 7pm.

We are excited to have Andrea Binder and Rob Henry, who has been instrumental in marriage equality and changing policies, to lead this introduction. This is your chance to have you and people you care about come together, check out the Landmark Forum, discuss what's important to you and your community and create a new possibility for yourself and LGBTQ community.
results.name: Community Introduction for LGBTQ Community

results.description:
This event is the first in what may be a series of lectures sponsored by the Sitzundjibers. 

Len May will be hosting a complimentary Seminar in Wayland.

This event will be held Tuesday Sept. 1, 7:00-8:30pm in Wayland.  The information to be presented pertains to both men and women; and the younger one is when they start a plan, the more money they save over the long term.  If you would like to attend or if you would like more information, please email <a>[masked]</a>. 

Background information: According to government statistics, at least 70% of people over age 65 will require long term care services at some point in their lives. (see www.longtermcare.gov) This presentation covers the consequences and the options for preserving assets, enabling choice in terms of where care is provided, and avoiding burdening others. Len has given this seminar over 25 times to various adult education programs, which typically charge between $25-$40 for the single session. However, there will not be a charge for this event!

Unfortunately, the last reasonably priced straight long term care insurance offering for single women is terminating on Sept. 20, so now is the time to learn about it.  (All the carriers are going to “gender based” premiums, meaning they are charging women much more than men, as historically women have received the majority of the claims payments.)

Our host: Len transitioned to a career in long term care planning and insurance from high tech after he saw the consequences of both of his parents needing extended care.  He is an independent, certified long term care specialist and shares his expertise by conducting seminars for consumers.  He also partners with financial planners, estate planning attorneys, and CPAs to help them educate their clients on the importance of long term care planning. 


Space is limited, so contact Len  (<a>[masked]</a>.) ASAP
results.how_to_find_us: Contact the host, Len May at lenmay@comcast.net or 508-276-1047
results.name: A Complimentary Seminar on Long Term Care Planning by a Sitz Member

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 9/1 Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
The meetings are in Beth Israel Deaconess Needham Campus (the Old Glover Memorial Hospital). If you have suddenly found yourself widowed at a young age, or if you were widowed in the past but would still benefit from interaction with others in the same situation, please join us. An informal , peer supported, drop in meeting held on the 4th Tuesday of every month from 7 - 8.30pm. The discussions cover topics such as family, work, financial changes, social changes, grieving through the holidays and finding the day to day strength to move forward. Being widowed at a young age can be a very isolating experience. This group provides a safe and supportive environment in which to discuss day to day issues as well as larger questions about the future. Please feel free to join us at one of our monthly meetings.

Please note: Emergency Room Conference Room is not always easy to find!

Please park in the lower lot to the right of the main hospital building and enter through the side door. Turn right toward the Emergency Department. After passing through the ER department take a left as if to go to the elevators. Follow that corridor all the way around to the right and ER Conference Room  will be on your right. I will have a sign posted on the conference room door as well as one in the ER hospital entrance foyer, which will have an arrow directing you where to go.
results.name: The Boston Young Widow and Widowers Group Monthly Meetup

group.name: The Boston Area Young Widow and Widowers Group

results.description:
The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act has handed down many new changes, and now the changes to the HUD-1 and closing process is upon us.  One of our REIA sponsors, Amanda Tiernam, from Liberty Title Services, LLC in Boston will be joining us to explain what it all means and the ways that it changes business for us.  

                            Amanda W. Tiernan, Esq. 
                                      Liberty Title 

The HUD-1 settlement statement and Good Faith Estimate forms are going away on August 1. The Truth in Lending Act disclosure is going away as well. In their place will be a new closing disclosure and a new loan estimate. There will be changes to the closing process as well, including a new rule requiring everything to be in place three days prior to closing. And last-minute changes face new hurdles. Learn about the changes in this walk-through  

Join us for our September General Meeting to learn the ins and outs of these changes and take time to meet Amanda to see what he can do to support your business as you move forward!  We will take time to talk about the proper ways to ASSIGN a contract, double close a wholesale, and use or offer private money as it relates to closing and title. 

There will be a Q&A Session following the presentation!


We have merged with the Boston Real Estate Investors Association!

The Boston Real Estate Investors Association  is open to real estate investors of all experience levels who want to meet and continuously learn from other investors and real estate professionals. Each meeting features knowledgeable speakers to guide members through new and relevant topics relating to the many aspects of Real Estate Investment. Past events have covered Why invest in Real Estate?, Foreclosures, Self-directed IRA's, 1031 Exchanges, and Creative Tax Strategies.

It's an opportunity to network with others who share similar goals & needs, to learn about unique & hot properties, to find ways of obtaining & utilizing different sources of capital, and so much more!

Find more about us at www.BostonRealEstateInvestorsAsssociation.com
results.name: New HUD1 Closing Regulations - Assignments, Double Closings, and more..

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

A 2 Month introductory course for individuals already trained in modern Epee or another fencing weapon. We will cover the additional elements of smallsword the lethal dueling weapon which epee is derived from.

New concepts will include:
* Circling the enemy
* Using the off-hand
* Grabbing their weapon
* The hanging guard
And more

Class begins on September 1st and meets Tuesdays at 8:15 and Saturdays at noon.

The class is specifically designed for folks already familiar with the epee. A variety of experience levels can be accommodated because the small class size allows instruction to be customized to the student.

Be prepared to sweat and move.

Weapons will be provided.

Course is $175, preregistration is required.

results.description:
Join us for our next FREE Dating and Relationship Teleseminar

"3 Golden keys to Free Yourself From Any Fears" With Guest Speaker Sally Stubbs, Psychotherapist and Relationship Expert

FREE Pre-Dating Teleseminar

WHEN: Tuesday, September 1st, 2015 from 8:30 PM to 9:45 PM (ET)
SPEAKER: Sally Stubs, Psychotherapist and  Relationship Expert
WHO'S INVITED: This Teleseminar is Open to EVERYONE 
HOW MUCH: Complimentary! 
HOW TO RSVP: http://predatingteleseminar.eventbrite.com 

"3 Golden Keys to Free Yourself From Any Fears"
With Guest Speaker Sally Stubbs, Psychotherapist, and Relationship Expert

Find your 'MoJo' and have Great Dates & Harmonious Relationships

In this Informative Teleseminar, you will learn:

How our fears hold us back from being our self & relating joyfully. Where our fears come from & how we can thoroughly deconstruct them “Golden Key One”: why we need self-worth in our important relationships and how we can develop the right kind of self-worth “Golden Key” Two: How self-worth creates healthy and vital ‘boundaries’ in our important relationships “Golden Key” Three: Gaining the essential Power Balance in an important relationship – and Restoring your own ‘MoJo’

PLUS All attendees will receive:

Deep discounts on Pre-Dating Speed Dating Events

Sally Stubbs Protocol: “Find your ‘MoJo’ – and have Great Dates & Harmonious Relationships” ($18.97 Value) A Chance to win one of 6 Free 1 hour Therapy Sessions ($236.00 Value)

ABOUT OUR SPEAKER - Sally Stubbs: Sally, from being a young child was enthralled by the power of the individual mind, particularly the Unconscious Mind. From the age of 10 she was reading as much as she could to learn about the mind and the potential of every individual mind. She studied Psychology and para- Psychology, also studying extra curriculum from Ancient Traditions and our amazing Neuro Sciences. She went on with formal education and Qualified in 1982 as a Licensed Psychotherapist and Clinical Hypnotherapist MBCP Snr. Accred., FACH, CNHC, NGH. Her Passion and rigorous research over the past 33 years has been focused on how to have: Authentic, lasting Harmonious Relationships. She has Worked successfully with 1,000’s of people from around the world, is a published author, and is much sought after for her Unique & Authentic Therapeutic strategies.

Sally has presented and has been a speaker in many countries. She worked during the 1990’s as a Consultant to the Juvenile Justice team. She has written many articles for Professional Journals and has been a BBC Radio Presenter as an ‘Agony Aunt’ – resolving relationship issues. Above all that, Sally would like to share with you how she, from being a very nervous, withdrawn, and fearful child freed herself from her own fears, ‘found’ her own ‘Mojo’ – met and married Mike, and has lived in a loving, adventurous, harmonious relationship that Rocks- for nearly 25 years!   

<a href="http://www.pre-dating.com/teleseminar/"></a>

results.description:
After finishing up your Allston Christmas shopping, feel free to head on over to Great Scott on Sept 1st to join me in catching Tamaryn as she swings through the area.

The project started out as a duo comprised of Tamaryn and Rex John Shelverton, who made excellent, spacious shoegaze music together. But now Tamaryn herself is working with new collaborators and pushing her sound further, making ethereal rock music with a somewhat poppier and synthy feel that still keeps in line with her earlier sound--even making the influence of acts like the Cocteau Twins, My Bloody Valentine, and Siouxsie and the Banshees more overt.


As for the songs, I'm really enjoying the pop turns "Hands All Over Me," and "Last," and the 80s goth-tinged "Softcore." I think she's only playing new songs, but maybe we'll luck out and get to hear renditions of songs like "Love Fade" or "Mild Confusion."


I'll be quite easy to spot, as I imagine I'll be the only dude limping around Great Scott with a cane. I'm still nursing a sprained ankle, and will want to grab a chair pretty early on, so let's meet at one of the tables that are to your right when you enter the bar. I'll see if I can grab the one closest to the stage and sound booth. (I don't want to hold anyone back, if you want to get closer when the bands are playing, feel free.) I'll also email the people who are coming with my contact info as the day gets closer.

Doors are at 9, so I'll aim to get to Great Scott around then. The opener is Gambles. Hope to see you there!
results.name: Tamaryn @ Great Scott

results.description:
REGISTER USING THE EVENTBRITE LINK BELOW!

Learn to build APIs using Node.js and then build a hybrid mobile app using the Ionic framework (HTML/CSS/AngularJS/Apache Cordova) that consumes the APIs in this all-day, hands-on developer workshop, sponsored by Apigee.

Whether you're a seasoned developer or not, this workshop will cover everything you need to know to start building APIs and hybrid mobile apps -- including a crash course in Node.js, and a crash course in AngularJS for those that need to get up to speed. And even though the workshop is focused on developing a hybrid app, everything learned in the workshop regarding API consumption can be applied to native (Obj-C, Java, C#), .Net, Ruby or traditional web development as well.

This is NOT a sales or marketing workshop - in fact, everything we use is free and open source! The goal of the workshop is to give back to the community by providing attendees with a basis of knowledge to get started with API-driven app development, regardless of skill level.

It all kicks off at 9am and runs until 5pm. Lunch and beers/wine (afterwards) are provided by Apigee. You can find all the details and register at: https://api-to-app-boston.eventbrite.com
results.name: (Date Rescheduled) Free Workshop: From API to App with Node.js and Ionic

results.description:
Requirements:

• Must be a Massachusetts licensed real estate agent to attend.
• Seating is limited to the first 15 registrations


Most real estate agents have 2 revenue streams: 

1. Working with buyers to purchase a home for them to live in and

2. Working with sellers by listing and their home. 

Learn how to add additional revenue streams to your real estate business by attending this lunch and learn event hosted by Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development. The presentation will focus on adding additional revenue streams to your real estate brokerage business including:


1. Making money by helping us acquire properties: Think it would be easier to approach an expired listing or FSBO with an offer in hand from a cash buyer?  We'll show you how to easily get in front of more sellers.
2. Our Automated Short Sale System:  Learn how to capitalize on short sales while keeping your sanity.  Our automated short sale program allows agents to spend a very limited amount of time and effort while maximizing their commissions.
3. Buyer Lead Overflow: we don't work with buyers, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't.  Learn how working with an investor can provide you with an overflow of buyer leads and how we generate these leads(mostly by accident).
4. Learn how to make money by wholesaling properties & raising capital: we'll show you how to easily and effectively add these two revenue streams to your real estate business.

As an added bonus, we will be reviewing our best practices and systems to allow you to leverage your time and efforts in 2015.  

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has acquired over 62 properties to fix and flip over the past 12 months. Environment & Structure of Event: The presentation will be held in our conference room in Wakefield and we will be providing lunch and refreshments. Seating is limited to the first 15 registrants and the presentation will be followed by a Question and Answer session. The presentation and Question and answer will end at approximately 12pm and for those who want to stick around or have additional 1 on 1 questions we will be ending at 12:30pm.
results.name: Making Money w/Ocean City - Lunch & Learn - Creating  Additional Revenue Streams

results.description:
Do something different for lunch! Join us for a fun, informative walk with the plants along the Charles!

There are over 40 different species of medicinal plants growing along the Charles River between Harvard Square and Central Square!

The ability to identify and use each of these plants was once commonplace to every man, woman, and child, but today most of us have lost that knowledge. Come reclaim what’s yours! Join us regularly throughout the spring, summer, and early fall and learn the plants in all of their stages of growth. By the end of these sessions, you’ll feel confident in your ability to identify the plants along the river – and you’ll how you can work with them!

Wednesday, September 2nd, 2015  
12:15pm – 1:15pm

a map of our meeting point can be found here: 
http://commonwealthherbs.com/charles-river-herb-walk/

Meet at the Harvard Weld Boathouse on the corner of JFK and Memorial Drive between noon and 12:15 – look for the herb walk sign! We’ll leave promptly at 12:15, and return by 1:15. Feel free to bring a notebook or sketchbook, camera, etc. The fee for the herb walk is $5.

Herb walks are “Sprinkle or Shine!” – if it’s just damp or a bit drizzly, we’ll walk anyway. If it’s raining enough to need an umbrella, that makes it hard to learn, so we will cancel in that event.
results.how_to_find_us: http://commonwealthherbs.com/charles-river-herb-walk/
results.name: Charles River Herb Walk, Cambridge

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Do something different for lunch! Join us for a fun, informative walk with the plants along the Charles!

There are over 40 different species of medicinal plants growing along the Charles River between Harvard Square and Central Square!

The ability to identify and use each of these plants was once commonplace to every man, woman, and child, but today most of us have lost that knowledge. Come reclaim what’s yours! Join us regularly throughout the spring, summer, and early fall and learn the plants in all of their stages of growth. By the end of these sessions, you’ll feel confident in your ability to identify the plants along the river – and you’ll how you can work with them!

Wednesday, September 2nd, 2015
12:15pm – 1:15pm

a map of our meeting point can be found here:
http://commonwealthherbs.com/charles-river-herb-walk/

Meet at the Harvard Weld Boathouse on the corner of JFK and Memorial Drive between noon and 12:15 – look for the herb walk sign! We’ll leave promptly at 12:15, and return by 1:15. Feel free to bring a notebook or sketchbook, camera, etc. The fee for the herb walk is $5.

Herb walks are “Sprinkle or Shine!” – if it’s just damp or a bit drizzly, we’ll walk anyway. If it’s raining enough to need an umbrella, that makes it hard to learn, so we will cancel in that event.
results.name: Charles River Herb Walk, Cambridge

results.description:
We need to get the following information into the hands of EVERY DIRECTOR of a KILL SHELTER in the US as well as BOARD MEMBERS and supporters of those shelters.   Due to a generous grant from a supporter, the NO KILL ADVOCACY CENTER (not to be confused w/organizations with similar names) is making the following offer. We need YOUR HELP! Please post to the Facebook page of EVERY KILL "Shelter" you can think of- as well as every pro-animal group.  Please also email info to shelter directors & board members of Kill "shelters" (contact info below).   Please make it clear that you are NOT a member of any group but are writing as a private citizen.   IMPORTANT:  Always be extremely polite & assume they will stop the killing once they understand how it can be done.

We CAN SEE a NO KILL AMERICA in our lifetimes!
---

FREE to a GOOD (or bad) SHELTER

Are you a SHELTER DIRECTOR? Attorney Nathan Winograd, former Director of Operations for the SF SPCA and Director of the No Kill Advocacy Center, would like to show you- FREE - how ANY SHELTER can become NO KILL - while TURNING A HEFTY PROFIT! For your FREE COPY of the book "REDEMPTION- the No Kill Revolution in America" as well as a your FREE CD with over 200 documents, including “how to” guides, sample policies and procedures that will guide you, step by step, in implementing this proven model, please send a letter on official letterhead to:

No Kill Advocacy Center
6114 La Salle Ave. #837
Oakland CA 94611

The fine print: No emails. U.S. addresses only. Only one per shelter. Under the terms of the grant, this offer does not apply to foster-based rescue groups. While supplies last. For a schedule of screenings of documentary film REDEMPTION: The No Kill Revolution in America (based on the book), please go to www.nokill.org

Note:  (copied from original discussion on August's "virtual event"): a list of the 10 highest kill shelters is available here:   http://www.advocateforsavingdogs.org/highkillshelterslist.html

I posted on lots of sites and wrote the director of a shelter in Augusta, GA - will continue on down the list. I think it might be good strategy, though, to start with the shelters in your town and then state. You go to webpages to find staff members and mail them. I would cc several people at a shelter- my logic being that maybe *one* will be receptive. We can also email members on the boards of directors

PLEASE:  remember to be extremely polite, and always assume the directors are just not aware of the no-kill model and would certainly implement it if they knew how.

IMPORTANT:  Please make it clear that you are writing as a private citizen, and not as part of an organized effort

For more discussion on which states have been covered, etc, please see original discussion at august's virtual "save lives" event.

WE CAN DO THIS!
results.name: SAVE LIVES!

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!! 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 


TALK with us FIRST !! 

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas 

Vegan Cooking Classes or 
                 Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food 
                    (using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 

* What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?
* Portion Control
* Bake...Don't Fry!
* Roasted Veggie Stackers
* No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream
* Avocados!!!
* Salad with Chipotle Hummus
* Simple Cilantro Chutney
* More $2 bags of Produce!
* Drink your greens!
results.name: VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill - Take home 1-2 bags free

results.description:
Tomorrow  is going to be a hot one pool  officially closes for the season on September  7th 😥 .

Bring your swimsuit and flip flops and be prepared to just chill and relax and enjoy the pool.

To make it simple, we can order from Giovanni’s and have them deliver. You can bring snacks/refreshments to share if you would like.

Please note there is no glassware of any kind allowed in the pool area.  If you have something that is in a glass container you will need to keep that in the clubhouse.

There is a $3.00 guest fee that you will need to give to the pool monitor when you arrive.

When you arrive in the complex just go straight and you will see the clubhouse and pool on your left and on your right there is parking and a small parking lot and walk up the walkway to the left of the clubhouse.

Call me on my cell when you arrive so I can let you in[masked]-0136.

We'll meet up at Stoney Brae Playground at 5pm. Even if you don't have kids feel free to come out, grab some free food and hangout.
results.name: Neighborhood Block Party

results.description:
Hi All,

We will be playing outdoors at Bird Park in Walpole on Wednesday at 5:30 pm.

Here is a link to a map with a blue push pin indicating the lot we normally park in and a blue star indicating where we set up the field:

https://www.google.com/maps/d/edit?mid=zsgWnosyJyWw.kkMDppD2npzk

There is no cost to play.

In order to play we need to know if we have enough players.  So, if you are planning on coming, it is important that you RSVP otherwise we'll have to cancel.

I'll send out a confirmation Wednesday afternoon to let you know whether the game is on.

Remember to bring a white and dark shirt (no grey) as well as your soccer gear to work in case we play.

Thanks,

-Dave
