results.description:
Hi All!
A number of you have shown interest in a weekday evening meetup in the downtown Boston area. Here it is! Please come and join us for a casual 2 hours ASL social on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 7:30 pm.


WHO: All who are interested in ASL are welcome to join us. Whether you're Deaf or hearing, beginner or fluent ASL user, we're here to share and socialize in this beautiful language.

WHERE: We'll be in the City Place Food Court in Dept of Transportation Building (use entrance on Boylston Street across street from Boylston Street T stop or entrance on Stuart Street) . Since we'll most likely be the only group of people signing, we should be pretty easy to spot.

RULES: Voices off, use paper and pen if you need to--this helps us learn and its Deaf friendly


RESOURCES: For those of you who are new to ASL and want to come prepared, here are some very good websites with free online classes.

http://www.westwoodasl.com/ http://www.lifeprint.com/ http://www.start-american-sign-language.com/

RSVP: Please RSVP for the meetup that you will be attending so we know how many people to expect.

CONTACT: Please feel free to contact host (Sean) if you have any questions or concerns. Hope to see you there! :)
results.how_to_find_us: Look for people signing!
results.name: Downtown Boston Weekly ASL Social

results.description: Wednesday evenings are a great mid-week option - we are making this a regular weekly meetup, so you can count on getting your tennis fix. The Cambridge Public Library has 3 tennis courts that are open and free. If the weather is good, there may be others already playing, so we will have to share the courts. Use the meetup discussions and RSVPs to coordinate with each other, and hope you get a good game of tennis and make new friends!
results.name: Wednesday Evening Mixed Doubles

results.description:
This is an open event and all types of games and gamers are welcome! Ages 12+

Come join the Dover Town Library for an evening of gaming and fun! We’ll be playing whatever type of games happen to find their way into the evening–card games, Euro-style board games, mahjong or whatever else you want to bring along. Food and drinks are encouraged but not provided.
results.name: Game Night at the DTL

results.description:
RSVP by phone call only


$11.00 / lb. for food; soup $3.50 / cup.

Call no later than 10:00 AM on Wednesday if you want to get food that evening – <a>(781)[masked]</a>

Order by phone only. No e-mail please. Thank you.      

Menu    9/02/2015

*Ingredients will be changed sometimes. 

*I use organic ingredients as much as possible (90%~100%).

*In the menu, SALT is Atlantic sea salt, OIL will be Light sesame oil, roasted sesame oil, sunflower oil or safflower oil. 

Soup    /Kidney Bean, Zucchini, Corn, Fennel, Leek, Bay Leaves, Salt, Oil

Grain   / Brown Rice, Sweet Brown Rice, Salt

Pickles /Italian Parsley, Cabbage, Blanched Cauliflower, salt, Olive Oil

Greens /  Sauteed Romaine Lettuce, Mung Bean Sprout, Carrot, Salt, Oil 

Side 1/ Tofu, Onion, 100% Buckwheat Noodle (GF) Dried Shiitake Mushroom             Sauce: Raw Grated Daikon, Tamari, Lemon Juice

Side 2/ Roasted Delicata Squash, Buttercup Squash, Red Miso, Oil, Salt, Pumpkin Seeds with Upland Cress as Garnish 

VEGAN MACROBIOTIC MEAL
Cooked by Tomoko Shibuya
Every Wednesday evening
Eat meal here or pick up to go
5:30 – 8:00 PM Wednesdays
8 PM is the last serving. You are welcome to stay longer.

Tomoko Shibuya's home
10 Belknap Street, Arlington, MA 02474
[masked]
results.name: Vegan Macrobiotic Wednesday Dinner in Arlington

Starting 7/1, we are going to meet at the garden side area where there are tables and chairs. It's indoor. Across P.F.Chang.

See this map for detailed directions.
results.how_to_find_us: Indoor, garden side, across P.F.Chang. You can reach from the walkway across Barnes & Noble
results.name: Prudential Center Go

results.description:
We're trying one more weekday game!  Fingers crossed for nice weather, and hope you can join us!

Now that our section of Cambridge Common has finished renovations, we're back at our old haunt at the corner of Mass Ave and Waterhouse Street, just a stone's throw away from Harvard T station!


As long as the weather is on point and we have enough people to play, it's on! Charge is very nominal for kickball games - only a 1-time fee of $5 to help cover equipment costs.


If you can't make it right at 5:45, no worries! We'll play til it's dark, so just join in when you can! See you there.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on the grassy patch between the Children's Museum & the Barking Crab Restaurant

results.description:
Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
WE ARE BACK AT TRIANGLE PARK FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
SPOT is the airbnb of parking. Their mobile app (currently iPhone only) has created a mobile marketplace connecting those lucky enough to have a private, off-street parking space, and those on the hunt for one. Have a SPOT? List it for rent whenever your not using it. It could be 24 hours a day, during the mornings while you’re at work, or that hour every Tuesday that you’re at spin class. Need a SPOT? Simply open the app, select a SPOT that works for you and confirm your reservation. With over a million dollars in funding, expansion into a new market underway and an ever-improving app, SPOT is truly living up to it’s tagline and making it possible to “park easier”.

Mitch Gaynor, Director of Marketing for SPOT. -  SPOT aims to solve the parking crisis in the city of Boston (and beyond) by providing a marketplace for owners of privately owned SPOTs to rent out that space to commuters who are in need of parking, at lower rates than many of the overpriced garage spaces. Come learn how to create a mobile app, build a business around one and all the people and things required to take a crazy idea into a million dollar business.

Light refreshments have been provided by Microsoft.

Limited street parking available only.

Timeline:

6:00pm-6:30pm- Open Doors/Networking

6:00pm-6:30pm-Tour of Microsoft (Tours are available on a first come, first serve basis. Please arrive on time if you would like a tour. Space is limited.)

6:30pm-7:00pm- A behind the scence look at a mobile app company by Mitch Gaynor, Director of Business Development and Marketing, SPOT.

7:00pm-7:30pm-  Building  Your Own App by Gavin Bauman, Microsoft

7:30pm-8:00pm Q&A

P.S. SEATING IS LIMITED - FREE REGISTRATION REQUIRED   

RSVP HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/black-tech-boston-meetup-one-successful-mobile-app-companys-journey-from-the-bottom-to-the-top-tickets-18129261108

All of our meetups are alcohol FREE. This event is open to young adults and well behaved children! We are about inspiring the future generation of techies!


Can’t wait to see you there!

Best,

MJ
results.name: One successful mobile app company’s journey from the bottom to the top!

results.description:
Come out and meet and mingle with other Boston Science Fiction and Fantasy fans at our monthly Social Meetup! We meet for food, drinks, games, and excellent companionship. We'll be at M.J. O'Connor's (the Park Plaza location). They are reserving their entire 150 person back room exclusively for us! I'll bring some board games along. 


More about M.J. O'Connor's here: http://back-bay.mjoconnors.com/

Please keep in mind that there are a couple of M.J. O'Connor locations, we'll be at the Park Plaza location at 27 Columbus Ave. in Boston

LOGISTICS:

* There is no theme or agenda, just people talking about Sci-Fi, Fantasy, and geeky things that we like (and dislike). If you can't come on time, that's fine, we usually have a large group until 8:00 PM. M.J. O'Connors is open until 2am if you want to stay extra late, but they will open up the room to the public at 9:00pm.

* If you have SciFi/Fantasy Books or DVDs that you don't want anymore, feel free to bring them to the meetup and give them away (no sales, please). Be sure to take home anything that isn't claimed before you leave!

* There is no charge for this meetup, but the restaurant that hosts us greatly appreciates your business (and doesn't charge us a room rental fee), so please come hungry (or at least buy a drink). Also, please don't forget to pay your bill before you leave!


TRAVEL:

It's about a 5-10 minute walk from the Park Street T stop (Red and green) and a five minute walk from either Arlington and the Boylston stops on the green line

There are pay parking lots around. For example, the Motor Mart Garage (motormartgarage.com) which is just around the block and is $10 for up to 3 hours, if you come in after 5pm.

Here is a map to the location.

There are some metered parking spots for the those willing to drive around and be patient, but only a few.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the back room on the Park Plaza side of the restaurant. Ask for the sci-fi meetup and they'll show you the way.

results.description:
Bring your laptops! 

Coach Deborah Knight & Profile Photographer Jon Fischer join together to bring out the best IN you so that you attract the one that is best FOR you!

Do you know how to write an Attractive On-Line Profile that will get you closer to finding the Love of your Life! Did you know that you have approximately 3 seconds to capture someone’s attention! Do you know what your user name is saying about you?
Which profiles get the most response?

Do you know what the Red Flags are how to spot them; does your profile actually have any? Does your picture truly say what you want it to say?

Learn this and many more tips on writing an attractive profile along with many dating tips from Leading Relationship Expert Deborah Knight. http://www.coachdeborahknight.com/

Deborah will lead you through a hands on workshop designed to rewrite your profile for your greatest success. She will help you put into words the true essence of who you are and what you are looking for. Arrive prepared to work on your profile! You will need your laptop and or a hard copy of your profile for this workshop. With Deborah’s guidance you will be split up into smaller groups to help one another with what you have learned so that you will all leave with a more streamlined profile that showcases who you really are and attracts someone who is looking for those exact qualities!

Jon Fischer is a Boston area Photographer who specializes in Online Dating Profile Photos. Jon will share a few tips and explain his process of capturing your true essence. He will also give you a few tips so that you will be able to do that on your own so that you are better prepared to not only enjoy the process but love your pictures.

As we all know it’s that first photo that grabs someone’s attention, it is in that split second that they decide to look further or not. Why not give it your absolute best shot by presenting a genuine and attractive image that truly captures you as amazing as you really are so that the right person will be enticed to look a little further. Together this dynamic duo will walk you through the process of Online Profiles and how to successfully navigate the sometimes tricky terrain. Please check out Jon's website at www.thebeautyofyou.com

Cost: $25

Arrive early to socialize and enjoy some Beer, Wine and Hors D’oeuvres prior to the workshop at 7:00pm. There will be time to Mix & Mingle afterwards as well.

For important directions and parking info click here: http://thebeautyofyou.com/parking-2/

Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

Starting from the Greater Boston Running Company in Lexington, we will follow ACROSSLexington's Route A or Route B in a cross-country tour of the town. Pizza and beer/wine to follow at Upper Crust is always an option.


Both Routes A and B are flat to slightly rolling, and distances are about 5 miles. Surfaces are mixed, including packed dirt, grass, gravel, wooden walkways, and paved streets. Trail shoes, however, are not required.

results.description:
I am in love with Asian inspired food:

http://www.wagamama.us/restaurants/marketstreet-lynnfield

I tried this place recently and I was very wowed by some of my favorite flavors. So of course I have to go back, and what better way than invite some folks and enjoy the evening with company. 

I might be able to get there by 7:00, but because it is tight I'm saying I'll be there by 7:15. Hold a table if you get there before I do. I won't make the RSVP's until the day before, when I have some sense of the sign up sheet. If someone wants to co-host and get their early let me know. 

We can have a nice dinner and play a round or two of bananagrams afterwards, if people are up for it. For a weeknight I'm guessing it will be a little quieter, and they seem to have great customer service. They cater to anyone with food allergies in an extremely impressive manner. Another option would be to walk around and browse some of the shops, although I think they close around 9:00. 

As usual, please don't RSVP and then don't come. I don't want to play bananagrams all by myself, nor slurp down a bowl of ramen while staring at some empty chairs, and it kind of sucks when people just don't show up. If you can't come I just ask that you un RSVP yourself before the dinner starts, preferably earlier, and I won't count you as a NO SHOW. 

...because you wouldn't want to deny someone else the experience of Wagamama.
results.name: Ethnic Eats Moves North/ Wagamama on a weeknight

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
THE TRANSPORTER REFUELED

Frank Martin (played by newcomer Ed Skrein), a former special-ops mercenary, is now living a less perilous life - or so he thinks - transporting classified packages for questionable people. When Frank's father (Ray Stevenson) pays him a visit in the south of France, their father-son bonding weekend takes a turn for the worse when Frank is engaged by a cunning femme-fatale, Anna (Loan Chabanol), and her three seductive sidekicks to orchestrate the bank heist of the century. Frank must use his covert expertise and knowledge of fast cars, fast driving and fast women to outrun a sinister Russian kingpin, and worse than that, he is thrust into a dangerous game of chess with a team of gorgeous women out for revenge.

From the producers of LUCY and the TAKEN trilogy, THE TRANSPORTER REFUELED is a fresh personification of the iconic role of Frank Martin, that launches the high-octane franchise into the present-day and introduces it to the next generation of thrill-seekers. 

Rated PG-13

In Theaters September 4, 2015

http://www.thetransporterrefueled.com/

We also like to talk about just about anything else of interest (geek culture, technology, pets, etc.) and chill with like-minded people like yourself.

Just come. We enjoy having those conversations that you may find difficult to have with your family, friends, or coworkers. You may be surprised what friends you will find here.

See you soon.

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we meet to discuss Chapters 16, 17, and 18 of Keynes' "General Theory", as well as Chapters 16, 17, and 18 of Hazlitt's line-by-line critique of it titled "Failure of the New Economics." The readings are not required to attend our meeting.

READINGS:

"The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money" 
by J.M. Keynes 
Chapters 16, 17, and 18
http://bit.ly/1QDOIeY

"The Failure of the New Economics" 
by Henry Hazlitt 
Chapters 16, 17, and 18
http://bit.ly/1RKJIZk

STUDY QUESTIONS

1. What are the economic implications, for Keynes, of a man skipping dinner (or perhaps ordering chicken instead of steak) and holding his savings as cash? For Hazlitt?

2. In what limited circumstance does saving not necessitate future consumption or investment for Hazlitt? Does this happen often with cash savings? Even in this limited circumstance, might Hazlitt be wrong?

3. Suppose a farmer, instead of spending his money on whiskey as he usually does, saves up his money to buy a tractor that can double his output: What are the macroeconomic effects of this? Does it matter whether he puts his money in a bank or under his mattress?

4. Successful speculators buy when the price is high and sell when the price is low. When do money speculators buy? When do money speculators sell? How does this relate to the business cycle?

5. Keynes says, “Every act of saving involves a ‘forced’ inevitable transfer of wealth to him who saves, though he in turn may suffer from the savings of others.” What is he trying to say here?

6. Can cash savings increase or decrease with a constant money supply? If everyone doubled the % of their income they save in cash, what would happen macroeconomically? Would this be possible if investment and savings were by definition equal, as Keynes postulates? What would happen in a world of minimum wage laws?

7. What happens when a bank increases its loans without a corresponding increase in deposits, macroeconomically? What changes if the loan goes bad? What happens when a banking cartel or central bank does this? Is Keynes right that banks can expand the money supply at will without an increase in savings?

8. Is a longer production process necessarily more profitable? What would this assumption imply? In a market economy, what will happen to investment in long production processes that are no more profitable than shorter production processes?

9. Keynes hypothesizes that, with enough efficient state management of capital, the marginal efficiency of capital could be reduced to zero, i.e. investments won’t be more profitable than a savings account and so there will be no incentive to invest, and state or nonprofit management of capital will become necessary. Is this similar to the Venus Project’s hypothesis of a zero cost world?

10. Keynes introduces the concept of “own rate of interest” in Chapter 17. How does this do away with the interest/profit distinction?

results.name: Capital, Interest, and Money

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!

results.description:
Lift and expand your vibration in this high energy evening meant to provide a felt sense of union with the Divine. Expect to feel profound peace, openness, expansion, and divine love.  You will receive three crown chakra activations with time to lay down in between for integration. A guided meditation will start us on this journey as we create a luminous energy field around us. Sacred high vibrational music plays for the entire evening.  Expect to maintain higher consciousness, giving you a sense of non-dual awakeness....being with what is...total acceptance of everything within  you and outside of you.

We are all in our awakening process...becoming awake to the Presence within us and living, speaking, loving and creating from that place. To access and maintain that truth of who we really are requires us to let go of any limiting beliefs, habits, memories. Then we can more fully embrace and embody the higher consciousness of our true Self.

No matter where you are on your path of awakening, you will love this sacred way of being in divine energy! Whatever you want next in life, this program will help you achieve it with ease and grace. The Divine Presence becomes apparent as unconditional love and joy.

Judy guides this class based on her ongoing deep studies in the area of conscious awakening.  The sweet, profound results of expansion in consciousness occurs in moments. At these meetings we can freely express and connect with like-hearted souls as we share in these powerful energy transmissions. results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

It is open to everyone. Starting times are 7:30pm during the fall and winter, and 8:30pm during the spring and summer. The program lasts about an hour.

Weather

The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here.

Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

>>> Tickets <<<

Public Open Nights are open to everyone, however space is limited. To reserve a ticket for admission click this link which will take you to our Eventbrite page.  [see website]

Location

The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Ave. in Boston, right above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell to the Observatory is on the fifth floor right next to room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.
Information

For information, please call[masked]-2630.

The Public Open Night at the Observatory is held clear Wednesday nights from 8:30 – 9:30pm. Call[masked] for the status.

Source: http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/
results.name: Public Open Night - Coit Observatory at Boston University

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Join us again this Thursday morning before you head out to work for a guided meditation of Scripture in the Jesuit tradition of Lectio Divina (Sacred Reading). All faiths (or non-faiths) are welcome! Alice will be facilitating.


What is Lectio?

Lectio Divina is an ancient Christian practice of unhurried, contemplative meditation on a portion of Scripture following four basic movements: 

Lectio: a time of slow repeated reading of Scripture punctuated by the use of a bell or chime. 

Meditatio: A time of quiet reflection on God's words and presence. 

Oratio: A time of silent conversational intimacy with God. 

Contemplatio: A time of listening for God's words for us personally.

We hope you'll join us in this deeply enriching spiritual practice.

results.name: Lectio Divina Meditation (Sacred Reading)

results.description:
The Brigham Circle market opens at 11 am and closes at 6 pm. 

The Roxbury Crossing T station market opens at 12 noon and closes at 6 pm. 

Both markets accept EBT, WIC, and senior coupons and continue to participate in the Boston Bounty Bucks program (which doubles up to $10 of an EBT, of food stamp, purchase). 
It stays open until Halloween, OR until Thanksgiving if the weather permits.

While Mission Hill residents are the intended beneficiaries, employees and patients of the academic medical centers (AMCs) are welcome to enjoy the produce and the benefits of the hospital's health-intending generosity.

This year, we will have 2 farmers, as we have in the past: MacArthur Farm and Gary’s Farmstand Too. We will also have Great Cape Baking Company.

Greetings Branchfoodies! 

We're thrilled to announce the next Community Table in Boston on September 3, 2015 from 12PM-1PM at 50 Milk Street, 16th Floor! 

This Fall, Branchfood will be hosting a series of conversations to inspire connection and collaboration within the Boston food community. Mark your calendars for Sept 3rd, Oct 8th, Nov 5th, and Dec 3rd! 

Community Table is for eaters, entre­pre­neurs, and students of food to connect and exchange ideas. A model created by Babson's Food Sol, the design is always one table, one conversation, with the collective driving the content. People have reported finding partners, expanding networks, and reaching retail all as direct results of attending Community Table. 

Please RSVP to the meetup if you plan to attend and join the conversation to network, discuss, connect and learn from others doing awesome work in the city!


See you there! 
Lauren + Rachel

results.description:
Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

The focus is to be present in the moment, allowing thoughts and emotions to surface. We become an internal observer of these, fostering healthy non-attachment and cultivating a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
(this is not a Mosaic Jewish Outdoor Club of Massachusetts event) 
It’s Summer Camp for Grown-ups
      September 3rd – 7th, 2015
Held in Poconos of Pennsylvania
With a Pre-Trip in Philadelphia and
A Post-Trip down the Delaware
Come take your vacation with us!
Registration is now open. 
Standard pricing is available until July 22
NOTE: An RSVP to this meetup does NOT reserve you a space at this event. You must register and pay in advance at http://2015event.mosaicoutdoor.org.
Located only a short distance from the cities of New York and Philadelphia, the Jewish Outdoor Escape will take place at a camp with a multitude of outdoor options only a short drive away. 
• Activities that include: Hikes along the Delaware Water Gap, on the Appalachian Trail, and to waterfalls and other beautiful destinations.
• Cycling on dedicated paths· Whitewater rafting; flat water canoeing Picturesque, historic train ride along the Lehigh river
• Winery tour; a pontoon boat ride on scenic Lake Wallenpaupack Zip Lines and Obstacle Courses
• As well as the much enjoyed in-camp activities, Shabbat programs, swimming and a host of evening entertainment options.
Click here to go to Event Website
What is the Jewish Outdoor Escape? The Mosaic's Jewish Outdoor Escape happens every year during an extended Labor Day Weekend. It gives Jewish outdoor enthusiasts from all over the world the opportunity to spend time with each other in a Jewish setting, and enjoy out-of-doors activities.  We stay at a summer camp and the activities vary each year depending on the locale. Over 100 like-minded Jewish adventurers attend this event each year.  The experience will typically include hiking, kayaking, biking, nature walks, horseback riding, arts & crafts, dancing, workshops, swimming, campfires, field games, photography, swimming and some great surprises!
What is Mosaic? Mosaic Outdoor Clubs of America is a volunteer-run organization that allows Jewish adults with a love of the outdoors to get “back to nature” and have some fun.With 15 clubs located throughout the United States, Canada and Israel, our international non-profit, volunteer-run organization, promotes appreciation of the outdoors, nature, outdoor skills and conservation, while helping to build Jewish community and continuity.
It's time to start dreaming about exploring the great Keystone State over Labor Day. Come escape to Pennsylvania with us!
Click here to go to Event Website
REGISTRATION FOR THIS EVENT MUST BE DONE THROUGH THE EVENT WEBSITE AT: http://2015event.mosaicoutdoor.org/
but please do RSVP for this meetup to help communicate with other locals who are planning on attending. When you sign up for this meetup you will be placed on the wait list. We will move you to confirmed status after you register on the event website at http://2015event.mosaicoutdoor.org

results.description:
Want to learn how you can bring agile methodology and culture to your organization? Do you want to get your app running on the cloud within minutes? Do you want a technical infrastructure that supports continuous delivery? With IBM® Bluemix™ DevOps Services, you can develop, track, plan, and deploy software in one place.  From your projects, you can access everything that you need to build all kinds of apps.  You can work on your own or use the collaboration tools to work with a team.  After you build an app, you can deploy it to the IBM® Bluemix™ cloud platform.

In this workshop, we will briefly introduce Bluemix DevOps Services then get right into labs. There will be 2 labs.  First, we will deploy a simple e-commerce application and then second, we will deploy an application using the Watson services.  We will be deploying these into the cloud using the continuous delivery pipeline. We will discuss how to effectively use DevOps Services in conjunction with agile methodology to gain productivity and reduce time to market. You should be familiar with how to code in Node.JS or Java.  Also, come learn how to use your favorite development tools to deploy applications on the cloud in Bluemix!


Resource link: https://hub.jazz.net/
Still haven't registered for your free Bluemix account?   Sign up here to get started:  www.ibm.biz/cloudboston  

Presented by:
Priya Aswani, MSCS, Lean Six Sigma
IBM Cloud Bluemix DevOps Developement Manager (Growth Hacking)
@BluemixDevOps
https://www.linkedin.com/in/priyaaswani

results.description:
Greetings!

With the Unite conference being held in Boston a just few short weeks from now, Unity developers will be focusing on advances in VR! This month BUG is proudly offering stereo talks on VR, in a new venue and with free food!



Virtual Reality Meets Actual Reality: Challenges Integrating Diverse Hardware within Unity3D
- Vinny DaSilva

Description:
In this session, we will discuss challenges and potential pitfalls that can occur when working with a diverse set of hardware within the Unity3D platform. We will tackle hardware such as the Oculus Rift, Omnidirectional Treadmills, Joysticks, and Webcams. Each piece of hardware comes with its own set of challenges. I will discuss how we overcame some of these obstacles within Unity3D.

Bio:
Vinny is a Senior Software Engineer with Ohsome Interactive, a digital firm specializing in the experiential industry. Before Ohsome Interactive, Vinny spent eleven years in the Life Sciences industry and three years as a consultant specializing in cutting edge technologies and game development. Vinny has been involved with the Boston Indie community and has released games for both Mobile (iOS/Android) and PC.


VR Ins and Outs: Implement All The Things!
- Jono Forbes

Description:
A dive into how to implement the major VR headsets (Oculus Rift, HTC Vive, Gear VR, Google Cardboard), as well as various types of VR input: physical motion controllers (Razer Hydra, Vive controllers), optical trackers (Leap Motion), and traditional inputs (gamepads, keyboard + mouse), without letting the codebase fall into chaos.

Bio:
Jono is a developer and designer working on VRMT, a VR worldbuilding app coming to all VR platforms. He’s worked on a handful of PC, mobile, and VR projects at Defective Studios, and previously worked as a 3D modeler and animator.



Logistics:
Thanks to our sponsors! Unity and Akamai are generously sponsoring our meetup this month. Akamai will be hosting the event and providing free pizza and beverages!

Thursday, Sep 3, 2015
6 PM to 9 PM

Location:
Akamai Technologies
150 Broadway
Cambridge MA 02142

Please RSVP so we can ensure enough food and drinks for the attendees!


  See you there!
   - B.U.G.

Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
A Conversation about Leadership Strategies
with Edith Onderick-Harvey

Join us for a Fireside Chat with Edith Onderick-Harvey about her book Getting Real: Strategies for Leadership in Today’s Innovation-Hungry, Time-Strapped, Multi-Tasking World of Work. The evening will start with networking and continue on with a conversation with the author followed by a question and answer session. 

About the Book
Getting Real is for anyone who wants to take leadership to the next level and create results in today’s world of work. By using each of the targeted coaching sessions in this book, you’ll quickly develop different ways of thinking. By using the
action steps at the end of each session, you’ll not only think differently but behave as a different kind of leader. You’ll want to apply these new strategies, tools and techniques as soon as you put the book down. 

About the Author
Edith Onderick-Harvey is a recognized organizational and leadership development expert. She works with Fortune 500 firms, growing companies, and universities to design their organizations, develop their leaders and continually elevate performance. She has been quoted in The New York Times, Human Resource Executive, CNN.com and many others. To find out more, visit <a>www.factorintalent.com.</a>

Date and Time:
September 3, 2015
6:30 - 8:30 PM

Agenda:
6:20-6:40pm: Registration, mingling, and light dinner
6:40-7:00pm: Facilitated networking
7:00-8:00pm: Chat with Edith
8:00-8:15pm: Q & A with the audience
8:15-8:30pm: Optional networking

Location:
Microsoft, One Cambridge Center, 4th Floor, Hawthorne Room, Cambridge, MA 02142

Members: $20; Non-Members: $35, Workshop and Annual Membership: $105
You can add $14.99 to your registration for a copy of the book, which you can pick up at the event or you can bring $14.99 and buy one there. A light dinner will be served.

results.description:
PLEASE DON'T FORGET TO SIGN UP HERE TO GET ACCESS!


Let's join New England Software Engineers (aka #NESE) for a night of coding, good food, summer cocktails, networking and panel discussion at the General Assembly campus in Boston!!!!

Panel, Mobile Development
Take part in an interactive panel discussing about the state of mobile development across platforms and technologies! The panelist list is still opened (shoot an e-mail if you want to be one of them) will include Brian Rinaldi (Telerik), Jen Looper, Morris Singer (Verilume Inc.), Mike Hartington (Developer Advocate at Ionic.io), Philip Sidell (Cengage Learning), Giorgio Natili (McGraw Hill Education), etc.

Lab, NativeScript
What is NativeScript? It is a new, open source platform, created by Telerik, that lets you build true native apps using languages you already know - JavaScript, CSS, and XML. Join Jen and Brian of the Telerik Developer Relations team as we celebrate the Summer of NativeScript with back-to-back hands-on labs and extra special custom cocktails in between. We’ll work right in a browser - no "install-fest" required - to build an app.

In the first part of the workshop, we’ll learn the basics of building a NativeScript app and deploying to devices. After a short break and cocktails, we'll jump right into the second lab, where we will learning about building page navigation and layout, UI controls and how to manage them, and working with modules. By the end of the evening you’ll feel that happy buzz (not just from the drinks) from learning about NativeScript!

TACO BAR!
Come for the tacos, stay for the code lab! In addition to the NativeScript festivities, we will be featuring a taco bar from Anna's (examples: http://bit.ly/1NqBUIX) - pairing perfectly with app building and drinks :) 


Event agenda:

• 6:30 -7:00 Registration and welcome cocktails 

• 7:00 - 8:00 First Lab

• 8:00 - 8:15 Break and networking


• 8:20 - 9:00 Panel discussion


• 9:00 - 9:10 Break and networking 


• 9:15 - 10:00 Second Lab
results.name: NativeScript Lounge Lab and Mobile Development Panel

results.description:
Hello everyone, I hope everyone is enjoying Summer!

I just wanted to touch base regarding our forthcoming Death Cafe. Time is 7 pm to 9 pm. 

As always, I will provide cakes and tea. This time, there will be just two types of tea - a hot tea and an iced tea.  In the interest of getting into the subject and not to miss anything, it would be easier to just have simpler fare.

Just for information, I live on the second floor, and there is no elevator.  Street Parking is available.  Also public transportation, #39 MTBA - Bynner Street Stop either way;   Green Line, E. Heath Stop - end of the line, about an 8 minute walk to my house.  I will mark my house and my doorbell for convenience.

Once again, I suggest that everyone reads about Death Cafe (Deathcafe.com), so we are all on the same page.

We do not suggest anything, nor do we recommend anything, we are a group of people who are gathered to share and talk about Death/Life. Simply.  We are very respectful of each other and we try to make sure everyone gets a chance to speak.

Last time, we thought to have a topic which we could think on before the meeting.  So if you would be so kind as to respond with any topic you find interesting, thank you!

I am excited and so looking forward and I hope you are too!

With gratitude, Carolyn

results.description:
Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 6.25% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.

Here's a link to the movie.

http://www.merufilm.com


==========


In the high-stakes pursuit of big-wall climbing, the Shark's Fin on Mount Meru may be the ultimate prize. Sitting 21,000 feet above the sacred Ganges River in Northern India, the mountain’s perversely stacked obstacles make it both a nightmare and an irresistible calling for some of the world's toughest climbers. In October 2008, renowned alpinists Conrad Anker, Jimmy Chin and Renan Ozturk arrived in India to tackle Meru.

Their planned seven-day trip quickly devolved into a 20-day odyssey in sub-zero temperatures with depleting food rations. Within 100 meters of the elusive summit, their journey—like all previous attempts—fell short of the goal.

Heartbroken and defeated, the trio returned to their everyday lives. By September 2011, Anker had convinced his team to reunite and undertake the Shark's Fin once more, under even more extraordinary circumstances.

Winner of the Sundance Film Festival Audience Award for Documentary, Meru is the story of that journey, an expedition through nature's harshest elements and one's complicated inner demons, and ultimately on to impossible new heights.

==========

https://youtu.be/YvS6O9lVkkg

results.description:
For all you weekday people who don't have much time during the weekend!

I thought the sculpture had been taken down, but it is still up and I wanted to revisit it once more before they take it down later this year.


Here is the photo gallery from last time.

We will start with the illuminated underpath pavilions and South Station, moving north along the Greenway (Dewey Square, Fort Point Channel, Urban Arboretum, Wharf District, all the way up to the carousel, if you wish).

Part of the Greenway is the overhead art installation, the Echelman Sculpture. This is a very unique object, which looks like aurora in the city. Very challenging to find a good angle that does not have a street or traffic light in it, but rewarding when you find one. Also great shooting straight up. Shoot it with high ISO and very short exposure time to freeze its motion or make it blur at low ISO and longer exposure. Both work well and it's fun to experiment with that (and the settings).


Suggested equipment: good walking shoes if you want to cover the entire Greenway. Tripod, camera, intervalometer (special challenge: Echelman startrails??), super-wide or fisheye lenses, they don't have to be superfast, it will be fairly bright.


Sunset is 7:15, we will meet when it's dark at 8, the moon won't come up until 10:30.
results.name: Echelman Sculpture on Atlantic Ave Greenway

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.


The Thursday class also includes a grappling and dagger defense portion.
results.name: German Longsword & Grappling

group.name: Athena School of Arms - Historical Swordsmanship

results.description:
The first #MakeItNew of the fall brings us back to where it all began, with our resident DJs.

John Barera, Balti Moroder and Coralcola collect records old and new. Their interests expand much further than the dancefloor: John has a passion for rare soul and funk, Baltimoroder's abstract and ambient folders overflow and don't ask Coralcola about BabyMetal.

All of translates into what must be one of the most well-informed DJ booths in New England and one of the dancefloors most consistently on fire. And remember, it is free before 11pm. Get lit tonight.

Make It New with the Resident DJs
Middlesex Lounge
614 Mass Ave.
Central Square Cultural District
Cambridge, MA
Free before 11pm/$5 after
results.name: Make It New with the Resident DJs (Free before 11!)

(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

SCRIMMAGES

In the Fall/Winter (September - April), we have scrimmages every Thursday night (except holidays) starting at 9:00 pm at the Simoni Skating Arena in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
All players of all skill levels are welcome. Come and skate with us, or just stop by to meet the players and learn more about Boston Pride Hockey.

We typically gather at a local establishment, afterwards. You can just drop in, or feel free to contact us to get the name of someone who will be at practice that night so you will know who to ask for.

Full hockey equipment is required to participate in the scrimmages.

SCRIMMAGE SCHEDULE

[masked] Scrimmage Schedule

results.description:
Tickets HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sketchhaus-tickets-16995422767

Welcome to the sketch comedy event of the millennium. That's probably not an exaggeration. Much.

For the first time ever, EIGHT of Boston's premiere sketch teams are going to share the same stage on the same night, presenting sides of themselves you have never seen before. Each group is going to start off with one of their best sketches - polished, hilarious, well-acted. The cream of the crop, is what we're saying. Then they're going to dig into their backlog of rejected sketches - stuff that never made it to the stage for reasons of sheer terribleness - and they're going to do a staged reading of that sketch for your dark amusement. Each group is going to cap it off with a story about the genesis of their group: behind the scenes tales of madness and mayhem you'll have to hear to believe

Featuring the sketch groups you know and love: World of Hurt, Vitamin Snake, Baby Cut, Mister Bismuth, The Rekcus, Brainfox, Centaur Stevens, and of course, High Country. Is this the best way to kick off your September? Folks, it's the ONLY way.
results.name: SketchHaus Presents: SKETCH GENESIS

At this meetup:

• LEGAL OFFICE HOURS: Coolidge Corner Co-Working Meetup is pleased to support its member entrepreneurs, emerging companies and small businesses by hosting free Legal Open Office Hours.  Sign up for a confidential 30-minute session with experienced business attorneys Jan Glassman and Joel Sowalsky, from Daily General Counsel.  Jan and Joel will help answer your important legal and business questions on topics such as entity formation (choice of entity), strategic business planning, contract terms and negotiation, leases, restrictive covenants (Non-competition, Non-Disclosure or Non-Solicitation Agreements), venture financing, trade secrets and intellectual property, and employment issues (hiring, firing, independent contractors, salary, overtime), among others.  Please use the link below to reserve an appointment, prepare your list of questions, and we'll see you on September 4th!  Reserve a time slot: http://doodle.com/8t9ziwz7b3h2vtte


• DISCUSSION: scheduled for 1:00 PM

• OPEN WORKING: from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Stop by at your convenience. 

• LOGISTICAL NOTES:

1. FOOD - We are meeting in a synagogue that also hosts a preschool, which means it is a kosher and a nut-free facility. I will bring some light snacks to share with the group. If you choose to bring your own food, it must meet both the following standards: (a) is marked kosher with a hechsher or is a fresh fruit or vegetable, (b) does not contain nuts.

2. LOCATION & ENTRY - The building is at 384 Harvard St, Brookline, and we'll be in classroom #1 in the basement. Please enter through the door on Williams St and then follow signage. 

3. PARKING - If you are driving, there is a convenient public, metered parking lot off Fuller Street.

Microsoft New England Research & Development (NERD)

This venue requires a security guard glance at a photo ID before being allowed into Microsoft NERD.  

Microsoft New England promotes research, software innovation & community in the heart of the northeast.  Bostonians are pretty clever folks. From Ben Franklin to the Big Dig–they’ve been solving difficult problems in creative ways for centuries. And today the Greater Boston area is home to cutting edge tech companies, world class hospitals, a vibrant startup community, plus a few universities you might have heard of. So when Microsoft needed the brightest minds to work on tomorrow’s technologies, Boston was the natural choice. And we love our New England home. The people. The ideas. The history. The culture. The food. It’s what makes us Microsoft New England.

https://microsoftnewengland.com/ 

Legal Disclaimer 

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Cannabis Society community events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the Cannabis Society organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at our local events. The Cannabis Society does not distribute cannabis.


The Cannabis Society is Growing 

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Get in on the Labor Day Weekend Nantucket Cottage Rental!

Since this is a house share, this trip is open to only those who have attended at least trip with us in the past.  

To sign up, you must email me directly at [masked]. You will then recieve a short form via email to be filled out and sent in with payment (checks only).  We will hold the spot for you for one week.

Friday 9/4 - Monday 9/6 (3 nights/4 days) $425 per person  OR

$525 per person, 4 nights/5 days (Fri - Tue) OR

$625 per person 5 nights/6 days (Fri - Wed)

Two spots left for a room share in a very small room with 2 twin beds. Once you sign up by sending in payment, you will be added to the attendee list. If interestsed in one of these spots, email [masked].

There are 4 bedrooms total (2 Queen rooms, 2 rooms with two twin beds)

4 of you will be sharing a room with one other, two of us will have our own Queen Rooms.  Bathrooms are shared.  There is also an outdoor private shower.

Cost includes lodging only.  

House is fully equipped with kitchen supplies, linens, beach towels and chairs.

This is for those who are independent and self sufficient.  There will not be any organized agenda, but you are all welcome to decide together what you'd like to do. Some may want to do their own thing, others may want to arrange a trip to the beach, etc.  Most like to purchase groceries for breakfast and lunch, and go out to dinner with the group.  

Bus stop is right in front of the house and will take you to town or any place on the Island. 

The house is located 5 miles out of town in the Madaket area, 1/2 mile from Madaket beach.

This is the 5th year in a row we're offering this trip and it's always a sell out.

To RSVP - email me directly at [masked] and I will send you a short form to fill out to mail in with payment.  Payment is due within 1 week of reserving your spot. 

More details will be sent to attendees mid August.

This is  a very nice Cottage.  The last room available is very small with two twin beds.  Here's what it looks like:

This is a picture of the main floor showing kitchen and living room.
results.name: Nantucket Getaway

results.description:
MFA First Friday Social Art Evening Museum of Fine Arts (West Wing Information room),Address: 465 Huntington Ave, Boston, MA 02115 tel[masked]


<------

Save wait time in line by entering the rear (Fenway )entrance of the MFA since the front gets busy.

<---------

ORGANIZER: Jimmy he will have signs out on the back tables at the MFA Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All Members of ALL AGES that like Art and a relaxed social atmosphere!

Admission: $25 per person -- Free for MFA Members. ...If you are an MFA members please try to arrange through comments to help get other members of our group in as your guest for free. You can also try to get a discount pass at your local library get you in for free or $10 a Person. Hey we all need to save a few bucks for drink later right?

Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM. After that try to find us in the Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard its where the party is at. and it the big tall room with the huge green glass Chihuly art piece is in. Stay as long as you want. MFA First Fridays ends at 9PM the Museum closed at 9:45PM.

MFA First Fridays is on the first Friday of each month from 6:00–9:30 pm. Join us for fine art, music, cash bars featuring signature cocktails, and delicious tapas available for purchase. Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

Accepted forms of identification for First Friday entrance include:
Massachusetts Drivers License
Massachusetts Liquor ID
Massachusetts ID issued by the Massachusetts Registry of Motor Vehicles
Drivers License from any US state
Valid Passport (photocopies are not accepted)
Federal Identification (e.g. Military ID)

We can mix and mingle with fellow art lovers,  enjoy the art,  the music and sip on our lovely drinks. hen we can break off and look at some more art since the rest of the museum is open!

Hope you can make it out this fine Friday Evening out for some Art Culture and great conversations.

======================================================

Notes for Parking for the MFA: It will be busy and lots tend to fill up fast so try to get there early! Taking the T is your best bet!

Self Parking Options: Visitors to the MFA have three self-parking options: the Huntington Lot, the Fenway Lot, and the Museum Road Garage, all of which have entrances on Museum Road. The Huntington lot offers closer parking to the Huntington Avenue Entrance and the Fenway parking lot is more accessible to the State Street Corporation Fenway Entrance. MFA lost Park costs $$$ over $20 so be prepared.

Subway Take the Green Line E train to the Museum of Fine Arts stop, or the Orange Line train to the Ruggles stop.
results.how_to_find_us: Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM.
