results.name: MFA First Friday Social Art Evening

results.description:
The Museum of Fine Arts is open from 6PM to 9:30PM on first Fridays. The entire museum is open. In the Shapiro Courtyard (the indoor courtyard with the Chihuly green glass Christmas Tree and the restaurant) the MFA sets up a cash bar and a DJ. From 6PM its mostly at 40-60 set to talk. After about 7PM the volume of the music goes up, the 25-35 year olds arrive, and the event shifts from talk to dancing. The place often fills up a bit after 7, so don’t be later than that.

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/mfa-first-fridays

Museum admission and event ticketing. The event is free with museum admission, either for members or general admission ($25, $23 for seniors), either at the door or online at http://www.mfa.org/visit. Many local libraries sell discounted tickets, for example two tickets for $10. Also, many employers may have discounted or even free tickets for their employees, check your human resources department.

First Friday is separately ticketed (at no additional charge), even if you are a member or preticketed.  You need to go through the admission line to get a separate ticket.  The line is tolerable at 6:00PM, and way way bad at 6:10.

If people have dual memberships they can get others in for free. As we gather at the front lobby, we can figure out any ticket sharing arrangements.

Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

It's not complicated.  Just show up and find one or another of the Meetup groups.  Someone will point you to the right lines to stand in, and maybe share a ticket.


Transportation. Public transportation strongly recommended, parking is a pain. The Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Directions by every transportation mode at http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

Meeting up with others—how to find us. The Fine Culture in Boston and Culture Vultures groups meet in the Huntington Avenue main entrance lobby at 6PM near the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus (3 headed dog). Then we will head in at 6:10.

If you arrive later, as you enter the courtyard, look to your left, and meet us at the tables near the elevator station with the poster of the current show.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

After. The event closes at 9:30.  We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.
results.name: MFA First Friday—Conversation, Art, Music, Dancing

group.name: Fine Culture in Boston (and International Travel)

results.description:
This is a good event, you can be as social or un-social as you prefer.  Go to the art galleries, or there is a  cash bar, tapas for purchase, and dancing to music provided by a DJ in the courtyard, you may wander in and out as you like.

Admission is $25 and includes the galleries (free for members).

Advance tickets are available, suggested as the event can sell out. Members may order free tickets by logging into the MFA website, and non-members may purchase tickets that include general Museum admission. Tickets also available in person on the day of the event, first come, first served.

Link is to last month's event, but you get the idea ;)...

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/mfa-first-fridays-0

You must be 21+ to enter the courtyard, don’t forget proper ID!

Finding us:  There are usually Meetups in the back (to the left as you enter) with signs on tables, I’ll start there to greet people - if your profile has a pic I'll look for you.  Later I’ll be dancing – come to the dance floor and join in, or wander around the galleries and look at art.


*If you have a membership that allows for guests please feel free to post in the event discussion. Discount tickets can be found at your local library/or through other members who also have a museum membership. I don't know if these allow for First Friday admission.
The event has a max attendance of 400 people, and does sell out so, get there before 7:15 or take your chances.


The MFA is on the Green Line and there is also parking in the neighborhood.
results.how_to_find_us: Keep in mind that this is a crowded, busy event.  I will start in the rotunda (straight past the coat check) or just through into the information area by the couches.  Around 6:00 we'll go in, or people can split off to view the galleries.
results.name: Museum of Fine Arts First Friday

results.description:
ART, MUSIC, DANCING

Let's meet out in the lobby in front at the main entrance at 6pm. near the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus (3 headed dog). Then we will head in at 6:10 to make sure we get in. We will congregate and get some tables to the left near the big cube with the poster, which has the stairs and the elevator behind it.

Try not to be late, as it fills up quickly and then they stop letting people in. I am BIll, 6'4".

The cost of museum entry is $25, but if people  have dual memberships they can get others in for free, so if you have a dual let us know via meetup comments, or RSVP comment.

I will usually email my phone # before the event to attendees so if you miss us in the foyer you can call or text (preferred) if you can't find us when/if you get in.   Look at everyone's pictures so we know who is going.  I will try to bring a copy of the pictures and will keep an eye out to say hi & introduce people.

BE SURE TO GET THERE EARLY, AS THE PLACE FILLS UP AND THEY TURN PEOPLE AWAY.  You need a license or Mass ID to enter.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the Front Lobby, off Huntington Ave., at 6PM, by the statue of Orpheus and Cerebus (3 headed dog).  We will go in at 6:10pm.

• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Learn how to DJ with vinyl records with special guest DJ Rugged One.  This workshop will focus on both the physical and auditory differences between analog and digital sounds, as well as the differences between 12”, 10” and 7” records, records that spin at 33 ⅓ and 45 RPM, and spherical and elliptical cartridges.  A brief history of phonograph records will also be given.

DJ Rugged One has been in the game for many years and has firmly established a name for himself in the industry as a professional deejay and producer. Spinning at numerous bars, lounges & clubs, he effortlessly creates a vibe that keeps the dance floor packed. His passion for music naturally led him into the realm of music production, where he actively takes on remix projects and creates brand new material with a plethora of skilled artists. Rugged One earned his stripes during his years as a competitive DJ, placing as a finalist in many battles, never failing to intimidate and turn heads! He continues to be sought after and commissioned to create mix CDs for respected organizations in the hip hop realm, including Undergroundhiphop.com, Brick Records and others, all while juggling his own independent releases. Receiving notable praise in a vast array of publications & websites, Rugged has evolved over the years to become the "total package," a DJ who can satisfy the purest of hip hop heads, the wildest of college club-goers and everything in between, taking you on a musical trip in the process. He enjoys what he does and is a true entertainer. DJ Rugged One…the man, the myth, the DJ... go on, go on and GET DOWN!
results.name: DJing w/ Vinyl w/ Rugged One

results.description:
A Puja, in Sanskrit, means reverence, honor, worship and adoration.  It's used by the Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, and others -- as a ceremony to honor a very special occasion; it's also used more often as part of a sacred ritual/practice to support opening to the wisdom of the Divine -- your Source.  


_________________________________________

Here's what we are going to do:

_________________________________________

Intimate Puja Circles, created by Robyn, of Come Back to Love, will be the place to:

• Be playful with other yummy, juicy, soulful singles, and couples

• Learn and practice Tantra, yoga, meditation - the principles and practices of Sacred Sexuality

• Be in a room with folks who are willing to be honest, and open their hearts

• Experience deep connections with those interested in sacred sexuality, expanded orgasm, conscious relationship, spirituality  - people like YOU!

Tantric Intimacy (whether you are single or in relationship):

This special evening will begin with many invitations to connect with each other in light and playful ways -- always with the opportunity to go as deep as you choose.  Single or coupled, you'll experience Tantric Speed Dating as a way to say 'hello', get to know one another, mingle and connect.

Here's what Participants are saying!

"The class was great; I  really enjoyed it. Very different from my normal way of life, you did create on a small scale what I was hoping for....creating the possibility to feel a deeper intimacy."

"It's so amazing to walk into a room of "strangers" and walk out feeling in love with everyone!"

"I didn't think I'd be able to connect with anyone there.  I was so surprised, and delighted, how easy it was to enjoy myself with every man in that room! Thank you Robyn, for your excellent facilitation skills. I felt totally safe!"

"We have to wait a whole month until the next one????"

"This is a very special event; a non-threatening, yet deep and authentic way to meet others. I've been online dating for years and it's just not for me.  I've met some really good people at your events."

"We love to come as a couple and meet others on a similar path."

The Intimate Puja Circle</a><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=SHVW639WM28LC"><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=ZES8HVDSP97PA"></a> itself will begin part-way through the night during which you'll have the chance to connect more deeply with others (one-on-one) -- this part of the evening will be facilitated, with a structure offered, however, you will have ample time to co-create with the beloved in front of you!!  You will be at choice and encouraged to ask for 100% of what you want.

Relax on a Friday night:

Once the formal part of the evening is over, there'll be time to dance, hang out, cuddle, snuggle, relax, process, and rest.  There will always be chocolate!


Q&A

1. What if I'm in relationship? Being in relationship definitely does not exclude you from coming to the Intimate Puja Circle.  These rituals will be invitations to connect with yourself and one another - and you will be at choice as to how you do that.  There are typically a mix of singles and couples at the events.

2.  What should I wear? Please be comfortable but also celebratory!  Wear yoga pants or something with a draw string around the waist; bring sarongs, scarves, dresses, etc.

3.  Do I need to bring anything? Yes, FRIENDS!!  And your water bottle.  You are also welcome healthy snacks to share after the Puja.  Organic fruit and chocolate are best.

4.  What if I have questions, I'm feeling a bit nervous:  Please email me to set up a time to talk:  [masked]

results.description:
Dance with us from 8:00 pm - midnight at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a class from 8:00 to 9:30 and continues with dj'd dancing until Midnight music provided by some extraordinary DJs. 

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

Come meditate with us every Tuesday and Friday at 8pm in our beautiful public meditation center. We offer a short (10 minute) introductory talk about a Buddhist topic and conclude with a half hour meditation session. Meditation is always free and guided in English. Everyone is welcome to come and explore their minds highest potential!

Street parking is available on the corner of Rockingham and Granite street and along Granite.  There is also a large parking lot with a Trader Joe's 2 minutes walk away from the center.

Cambridge, MA 02139

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: The field is a two-minute walk from Alewife station on the Red Line. There is also plenty of parking provided no one else is using the field. (Not an issue in the winter.)

venue.name: Gilliland Observatory of the Museum of Science Parking Garage

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.name: Astronomy After Hours - Museum of Science

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

results.description:
Organizer: Joe Ciarcia -[masked]

How to sign up for the WAITING LIST:
1. DO NOT USE A MOBILE DEVICE
2. RSVP yes
3. **** ANSWER ALL 6 RSVP QUESTIONS ****
4. Verify you've answers the RSVP questions by going back to the hike listing, click on "change RSVP", leave it set to "yes", click "OK", and you should see the answers to your questions, if not, answer them (there are 3 pages of questions (2 per page) and a button you must press after the 3rd page to confirm).
5. If you did not answer the RSVP questions, you will not be considered for this hike.
6. Make sure your Meetup settings allow you to receive email from the organizers, and make sure you actually CHECK that email address.

I will periodically review RSVP responses and add those who have answered all of the questions thoroughly and meet the requirements for this hike.

=========================

What We're Doing...

Join Kara and I (Kara has 4 legs for the uninitiated) while she hikes her penultimate NH 4000 footer.


NH4K - Cabot @ 4,170 feet
52 With a View - The Horn @ 3,905 feet
NH Hundred Highest - The Bulge @ 3,950 feet

Distance:           11.40 miles
Book Time:        7 hr 31 minutes*
Vertical Gain:   3583 ft
Projected pace: ~1.5 to ~2.0 MPH


* Book time does not account for snack breaks, pee breaks, scenery gawking, photo ops, silly walks, or alien abductions. It is provided as a reference only. DO NOT MAKE PLANS FOR THE EVENING with the assumption you will actually make it there.


Guests are not permitted. All participants are screened to ensure group safety, and to make sure everyone enjoys the hike.


Dogs are permitted only with approval from the event organizer (and they must be good with other dogs). Bring a leash, and a copy of their rabbies vaccination.


We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

You need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety. Overestimating your abilities may put others at severe risk.


What to Bring...


Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike* (*exception, NO COTTON EVER!!!):

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Weather...

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use this link for the current weather forecast:


http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.41357&lat=44.50574 Directions...


Travel time from Boston: 3 hours, 30 minutes (no traffic)
Meeting Place: York Pond Trailhead
Time: Boots on trail at 7:45 AM
Lat/Lon:[masked],[masked] (enter in to GPS or copy and paste into Google Maps App)


Use this link for customizable driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/qQof4

Carpools


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: NH4K, 52WAV, NHHH - Cabot, Horn, and Bulge

results.description:
I think this will be great for everyone - kids too !

Half price tix if purchased by Tuesday 28 Jan. Kids under 6 Free !!


How Does This Go Down?  Super Simple.
Clad in white t-shirts, Participants run, walk, dance and play across 3 miles of absolute fun! Waves start every 3-5 minutes. Then, at each kilometer, participants will run through the Foam Bogs where there is enough colored foam to cover you from head to toe!
Each of the four Foam Bogs along the course are represented by different colored foam.


There are a few simple rules.
Rule 1:All levels of runners, walkers, twirlers, dancers and strollers are welcome to the Bubble Run™.
Rule 2: Wear white. That way, your appearance at the finish will be even more pronounced.
Rule 3: Enjoy being a kid again.


http://www.bubblerun.com/events/boston/
results.how_to_find_us: I'll figure out a place before the date
results.name: Bubble Run - Very Kid Friendly

group.name: South Shore Hike, Bike & Social Club

results.description:
Explore the northeast section of Buzzards bay on this ~10 mile long level 2 paddle. We expect to paddle from Monk's cove, around Wings Neck, to Bassets island for lunch and leisurely break, and then return the same way. This is a reasonably sheltered trip, but we will paddle past the relatively exposed canal radar station on Wing's neck and should expect the Buzzards Bay afternoon seabreeze. This does create a bit of chop in a 1/2 mile section, so paddlers should be prepared to deal with 2'wavesp and 15 kt winds. Depending on the group and weather forecast, we may spot a car near Basset's island for those who don't feel like paddling through chop in the afternoon. This is a L2 trip: you must have a PFD and a 14' or longer kayak with bulkheads fore and aft, or proper buoyancy bags.

The start time and location on meetup are approximate. To attend this paddle, you *must* register by email with Jeff at http://activities.outdoors.org/search/index.cfm/action/details/id/85272
results.name: Paddle to Bassets Island in Buzzard's Bay

results.description:
We'll be sailing my Formosa-46 in the MA Bay area, from Quincy Harbor. The Formosa is a classic ocean going boat, elegant under sail, fun and comfortable. Find many pictures in the "Photos" section of the CrewFinder site. Or learn more about the boat's tech specs here>  http://sailboatdata.com/viewrecord.asp?class_id=2522

Your RSVP to this posting is an "Offer to Crew". While we are out having a good time, when serving as "Crew" you will also be involved in operating the boat, under my direction and as fits your level of know-how.

Build a reputation as dependable Crew: In advance of the sailing day be responsive, reachable through direct methods, and true-up your RSVP Status no less than 48hr before meet-time.

Use the Questions attached to the RSVP to enter your reach info, and find mine there. RSVP Q&A is private, not open web search, and preferred to putting personal info in the public forum. If you have given your contact info on a previous sail, please do it again. It's a convenience to have all the crew's info attached to the specific sail-day.

Use email, text or phone for time-sensitive comms. Messages sent through the MeetUp server suffer delivery delays and are not a reliable for contact in the 48hrs before the sail. Sending a note about change of plans? Use direct email, Not the message link on my Profile, and --especially-- Don't assume any note you enter on this posting will be seen on the day of the sail.

Learning to sail? Seasoned sailor? Social-boater? All welcome. Different sailing plans call for different Crew (as with racing, or a longer cruise). I balance the roster a mix of experience. Crew may change close to sail-day, and could cause your RSVP to be cancelled. This is not a personal rejection. The roster is unique to the day, your offers will still be welcome on a future sails.

Conditions can change while sailing. We're out enjoying water and weather that we don't control. A moderate day can easily turn rough. Please speak-up if you ever feel conditions are progressing beyond your limits. Come prepared with seasickness remedy, or advance prevention, if you've ever suffered motion sickness in other activities.

Sailing harnesses strong and unpredictable forces which put stress on the equipment, stir-up the ocean and make physical demands on all aboard. Injury is an ever present risk. When joining a sail, you choose to take this risk upon yourself and accept personal responsibility for your own safety. With this in mind, please make informed decisions whenever you Offer to Crew.

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be by the Lifeguard house
results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

Welcome all to the First Watertown Saturday club.

Toastmaster's Welcome 

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches


Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction


Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations


Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks 

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org
results.how_to_find_us: Park on Russell Avenue and enter Church of the Good Shepherd from Russell Avenue. When you enter, walk downstairs and take a left.

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $55 or $65 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

results.description:
Games, games, more games, and did I mention games. If you've attended Arisia then the library of games should look very familiar as they're using the NESFA game library for their game room.

 We've got something for everyone. Short games, long games, easy games, hard games, simple games, complicated games, and even a couple of games that don't require a brain to play.

 Not sure how to play a particular game? No problem. Myself and other NESFA members are experienced GMs and we're all too happy to teach others how to play. We're also always looking to play new games.

 You can also bring in a few of your own games that you want to play.

 There are also video game systems (a total of 5). Please ask before using, though, so the system can be set up for play.

 A new feature for the Game Days is the Star Wars: Imperial Assault campaign. This Game Day will feature the third scenario of the campaign. The Imperials haven't been able to win yet, but they came very close last game.

 Remember, there is absolutely no cost to come in and play, and you don't have to be a member, nor do you have to join. All you have to do is open the door. Hope to see you there.

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Sixteenth Stop...

Recently opened in Harvard Square, this rooftop expanse offers a wide range of canned craft beer and an impressive spirits list. Stick around after sunset and catch the sounds of whichever indie act is playing downstairs in their live music venue.

On the menu: Upscale bar snacks like fried chicken skins with ranch and Frank’s Redhot and bone marrow “tots” served with a peanut soy sauce.

GETTING THERE

The Sinclair is at 52 Church Street, Cambridge MA, 02138

Taking The T: You can take the Red Line or any number of T busses to Harvard Square. Follow the map below to get there: Walk down Brattle Street toward Palmer Street, take a right on Palmer Street, continue to Church Street, follow to The Sinclair.

Driving: If you're driving there might be on street parking, but it's tough to find, especially on a Saturday, and all of the surrounding side streets are resident parking only. There are a couple of parking garages though, and can be found here and here.

results.description:
Fitness doesn’t need to be intimidating or extreme, but it does need to produce good RESULTS! Come join TFW Boston for an after-work happy hour… errr I mean workout. Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!


What to expect:

A challenging, motivating, and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long day of work.

TFW signature workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, which has created world champions in multiple professional sports, and is individually-adapted for every person that takes part, even beginners!

Effective warm-ups to get you in the zone, and energetic intervals to invigorate mind and muscle.

Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives.


What NOT to expect:

Bootcamp instructors barking in your face.

Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.

Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.


If you want to have fun and lose fat, gain strength, and improve your confidence and health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend.

results.description:
How about a later day, intermediate hike, that explores some new territory? Lets climb Caribou Mtn (2850') in the Caribou-Speckled Wilderness located east of Evans Notch in the White mountains of Maine. There are no more Caribou but it does have open ledges with excellent views, a waterfall, and follows brooks for most of its length. This hike is entirely within a Wilderness area and will be limited to ten people.

==========================================

INSTRUCTIONS: You must answer the RSVP questions--if you do not respond your RSVP  will be deleted. Double check your responses to make sure they went through. Everyone will be waitlisted until responses are screened.

Please have your preferences for this Meetup set to receive messages from other members, in case I have further questions for you. Similar, recent hiking experience is required. Guests are not allowed, everyone must be a member and signup individually. Dogs are welcomed but must be screened for ability as well.

Weather conditions may cause this hike to be changed or cancelled. Updates will be given as we get closer.

=========================================

THE HIKE: We will use the Caribou Brook Trail and the Mud Brook Trail (which not muddy) to hike a loop over the peak. On our descent we will pass the 25 foot high Kees Falls.

There is an opportunity to explore some nearby areas after this hike depending on time and how people are feeling. I have a few ideas in mind, but it will an ad hoc plan.

Totals: 7.00 mi, 1900' of elevation gain, 4:30 book time

Level: Moderate to Intermediate

==========================================

PACE: We will hike together. Some people hike faster, some slower, some like to be in front, middle, or back. Some like to hike a steady pace, others like to stop often. By signing up we have all agreed to a general average pace of ~2.0 MPH which can be reached by any combination of these methods.

HIKING AS A GROUP: We will stop and regroup at all trail junctions, water crossings, or anywhere the trail may be unclear. What I like to suggest is that everyone hikes whatever way they prefer but stay with the group. Do not worry about keeping up with the person in front of you, but DO keep an eye on the person behind you. Someone will be the slowest person in the group. It may be you. Congratulations, you set the pace.

EQUIPMENT: You should be equipped for a 3 season day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing for a variety of temperatures (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, a hat, and basic first aid supplies. See the Ten Essentials and the Three Season day Hike List as a reference. Aardvark.

PROMPTNESS: Be ready to hit the trail within ten minutes of the meeting time. Some people arrive with their bag packed and dressed for the hike and are ready in a few minutes. Others come with everything scattered in their trunk and need more time to get ready. Know which one you are and allow the time you need to be ready on time.

DISCLAIMER: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: Caribou Mountain - Intermediate

results.description:
(A set of 6 Saturday classes)

Rapier – The word evokes images of duels, high adventure, and swashbuckling. Have you had a desire to learn how these swords were used in combat during the Renaissance era? Much more than shouting “En Garde!” and assuming a guard stance; competent warriors fought with systems that included various ways to attack and defend, footwork, timing, and even rules of dueling, all based on a sophisticated understanding of body mechanics, mathematics and philosophy.

The 16th century was a period of change for the sword. No longer relegated to the battlefield; the sword changed as its wear became commonplace in society. Blades slimmed and guards became more elaborate as the sword evolved into a nimble thrusting weapon worn by commoner and noble alike. As a result, a number of fencing schools opened to capitalize on their growing popularity. The golden age of rapier study dawned around 1550; numerous masters publishing fencing system manuals over the century to follow, with topics including rapier, off-hand companions such as the dagger, buckler and cape, long sword, quarterstaff, pole arm, dagger alone, and grappling.

Our six-week Novice Rapier course will introduce the basic techniques and vocabulary of rapier fencing, enabling students to begin their study of period combat and the Art of Defence. The course will be taught by Charles and Robert, rapier scholars and Schole of Defence instructors.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

We invite you to come join the scholars and combatants of our Schole!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes [August 22, 29, and September 5, 12, 19 and, 26] and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  Class materials will be sent via email before the first session.)

results.description:
Let's get back to prepping for Argentina. Time to book your flights/hotel. Please note it will be summer in Buenos Aires :)

Trip Date: Dec 4-13. However base date when members will cross path is Dec 8-11 so please book flights/hotels around this date range.

Flights-cheapest option is to book separate flights BOS-JFK then JFK-EZE (over $300 saved) During the last meeting we found package deals (flight+ hotel) at affordable cost starting at $1100-$1300 for the JFK-EZE route. Do note you can book straight from Boston but at a higher cost, the choice is yours.

Buenos Aires Ministro Pistarini International Airport (EZE) to the city center: 35km/21miles…35-45 minutes

Approximate fare: ARS 198 (The fares to the airport are lesser at approximately ARS 160)

Local airport is Buenos Aires Jorge Newbery Airport (AEP) Distance to the city center: 3km/2miles…10-20 minutes

Approximate fare:  ARS 25

Currency USD $ 1 =ARS $8.80 Peso (3/20/15) This fluctuates, the US dollar is currently strong.

Passport & Visa: US Citizens passport required. No visa required for USA/Jamaica. Passport/ID Validity: six months from the intended time of entry. No airport taxes

While no visa is required for travel to Argentina, a reciprocity fee must be paid online before attempting entry to Argentina. The fee guarantees each traveler multiple tourist entries to Argentina for tourist stays less than (90) days through the duration of the reciprocity fee’s validity:

If this fee is not pre-paid, you will be denied entry into Argentina. In addition to completing the requirements below, please consult the website for the Embassy of Argentina in Washington, D.C. for more information.

We recommend you pay your reciprocity fee starting (90) days prior to departure, but no later than (15) days before departure in order to avoid issues related to website malfunctions, et al.

How to pay your Reciprocity Fee:

- To pay the reciprocity fee, please click on the following link: https://reciprocidad.provincianet.com.ar/Registro.aspx;

- You will need to register for a free account in order to continue;

- Submit your personal data and credit card information (Visa, American Express or Master Card are accepted);

- Print a copy of this payment receipt; you will need to bring a hard copy with you when traveling to Argentina;

- The National Directorate of Immigration in Argentina will receive this information electronically, which customs officials will validate against your hard copy receipt upon arrival;

- When you go through customs, your receipt will be scanned by the immigration officials and your entry to the country will be duly registered.

No mandatory vaccinations

Language: The official language of Argentina is Spanish. Many Argentines can communicate in English, Italian or French.

Social customs: Argentines stand closer together when conversing than North Americans typically do. Dinner is usually served late, between 9pm and 11pm, and smart dress is expected, particularly in urban settings.

Tipping: Waiters in Argentina generally expect 10% tips. Porters expect also expect a small tip.

Electricity: Argentina uses 220 volts, 50Hz of electricity. The plug most commonly used is Type C, a dual round-pin attachment plug. Type I (dual oblique flat blades with grounding) is also in use.

Phone: The international code for Argentina is +54. To make an outgoing international call, dial 00, followed by the country code.

Emergency Numbers

Ambulance: 107
Police: 101 (911 also can be dialed in Buenos Aires and its surrounding areas)
Fire: 100
Others: Roadside Breakdown Assistance Services are provided by Automóvil Club Argentino (ACA)-[masked]

Neighborhood to stay in: Palermo area: Some Hotels in the vicinity are:

1.  Rendez Vous Hotel Buenos Aires (Kim booked here $462 for 3 nights) Bonpland 1484, Buenos Aires, Capital Federal, 1414 Argentina

2.  Mine Hotel Boutique

3.  Own Palmero Hollywood

4.  Duque Hotel Boutique & Spa

The above are just recommendations; there are many options in Buenos Aires. We need to know who would like to share rooms? Mary mentioned potentially booking an apartment via AirBNB so please check with Mary T if interested in that option. In the last meeting Thornton planned on staying in the Central area.

Things to do:

Free Walking Tours: tips recommended

http://www.buenosairesfreewalks.com/#_=_ OR http://www.bafreetour.com/english-home#_=_

Tango Lessons: some classes free @ Fundacion Tango Argentino http://www.fundaciontango.org.ar/english/tango-classes.htm

The Teatro Colón: world-renowned opera house known for its magnificent acoustic...

Flea Market Mercado de Pulgas: Inside this large warehouse, visitors will find numerous stalls selling antiquities, furniture, light fixtures, silverware, collectors' items and decorative objects, to name just a few of the offerings.

Museums: Fragata ARA Sarmiento-ship turned museum is one of the landmarks of Puerto Madero. In the late 19th and early 20th century it sailed around the world over 30 times.

Monuments & Statues: Parque de la Memoria-sculptures and a digital historic archive with photos, drawings and personal objects of the people who vanished during that period.

Day trips from BA: members expressed interest in this particularly if spending more than a few days. Some options just to get an idea are on http://www.viator.com/Argentina/d78-ttd

Let's get planning!

results.description:
At our first meeting, we decided that future meetups should include three components, at least for now: 

• Accountability check-in / hot seat

• Time dedicated to helping those without businesses GET businesses

• Time dedicated to troubleshooting and providing solutions for those who already have projects

We're going to give this new format a shot.

FIRST, we will go over techniques for brainstorming and researching ideas.  We'll watch a few videos and conduct exercises and that will help us separate profitable from unprofitable ideas (these videos and exercises come from over $4,000 of our members' paid services and courses).  After we've gone though the videos and exercises, we will discuss the ideas we came up with, poke holes in them, and focus on the ones that may be worth pursuing.

SECOND, we'll discuss whether any of the ideas presented may be suitable for a group project, where everyone would get a chance to learn and participate in the process even if they don't currently have a business of their own.


THIRD, if there's time, we'll troubleshoot attendees' current problems by providing suggestions, feedback, and resources.

Before you attend this meetup, please come with at least three initial ideas that you feel may serve as foundations for a business opportunity.  This could be very broad, such as an industry where you feel the demand is not being met, or you can simply "scratch an itch" you've noticed in your life that you feel may be indicative of a pattern.  For example, "in Japan they have these really awesome widgets, I wish they were in the US, it would make life so much easier."

The three ideas you bring to this meeting will be added to and refined by the exercises we go through as a group.
results.how_to_find_us: You'll see a sign just inside the front door.  Just go down the stairs and the conference room is on the left.
results.name: Profitable Idea Generation

results.description:
BOSTON’S POET LAUREATE VISITS BOSTON PUBLIC LIBRARY BRANCHES

Boston Public Library and the Mayor’s Office of Arts and Culture announce branch visits by the City of Boston’s Poet Laureate, Danielle Legros Georges, who will travel to Boston Public Library locations this summer to meet and engage with aspiring and practicing poets throughout the city. Interested participants can bring examples (please print 15 copies) of their work for discussion, or questions and comments for the Poet Laureate Program.

“The drop-in workshops from such a highly accomplished poet are a unique learning opportunity to develop one’s skills and celebrate creativity and the arts in the City of Boston,” said Christine Schonhart, Boston Public Library’s Director of Library Services for the Branches.

The following visits take place in Boston Public Library branches:

*September 5, 2015: BPL Dudley Branch, 65 Warren St, Roxbury, MA 02119

*October 3, 2015: BPL Hyde Park Branch, 35 Harvard Ave. Hyde Park, MA 02136

Danielle Legros Georges was appointed Boston’s Poet Laureate by Mayor Martin J. Walsh in December 2014 and teaches at Lesley University in the Creative Arts and Learning Division. She is the author of Maroon, a book of poems, and her poems have appeared in numerous anthologies. Her essays, interviews, poems, and reviews have appeared in publications including The American Poetry Review, The Boston Globe, Callaloo, Consequence, Salamander, spoKe, Solstice, Transition, World Literature Today, and the Women’s Review of Books. A resident of Dorchester, she was born in Haiti, has lived in Boston’s Haitian community of Mattapan, Chicago and New York, and has travelled to various parts of the world.
results.how_to_find_us: Dudley Branch Library is right across the street from both the Dudley Sq. Bus Terminal and the Police Precinct
results.name: Drop In at the Boston Poet Laureate's Workshop at the BPL

results.description:
Been walking by The Lounge's chess boards all summer, but too intimidated to play?

Time to toughen up and learn the brainiest of board games. Come Saturday afternoons for FREE novice and intermediate chess lessons. Classes are organized by skill level, not age, and all are welcome.

3:00pm - 3:45pm Novice
4:00pm - 4:45pm Intermediate

All lessons taught by Corey Tolbert: "Growing up in West Philadelphia taught me many important characteristics such as cunning, resilience, and will. These characteristics are what made me the player I am today. At 7 years old I fell in love with the game of chess. My grandfather taught me the game and we played thousands of games during my childhood. Along the way, I became the co-High School Champion of Philadelphia.

After over 75,000 games of chess played, I am always ready for more. I look for every opportunity to exhibit, learn, play, and teach the game that has been so great to me over the years. My goal is to play 200,000 games in my life and I am well on my way there. And if I happen to become the best blitz player in the history of mankind along the way, well that would make it all the better."
results.name: Free Chess Lessons

results.description:
https://www.facebook.com/events/440667196139098/

Date: Saturday, Sept 5, 2015
Time1: 3:00 PM to 4:30 PM: Advanced Beginner*
Time2: 4:30 PM to 6:30 PM: Beginner&

Contact: [masked] (please indicate you are coming for Beginner class or Advanced Beginner class, and if you are interested in the dinner or dancing options)


Soulful words in lovely, spirit-filled Chinese characters can inspire insight and add willpower in daily life. Dr. Sung, a native of Taiwan, is offering an interesting and informative workshop in Cambridge for all who love art and holistic works. Dr. Sung has a unique professional background in the field of education. Please see details below. In the first 30 minute of the workshop&, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice basic Tai-chi movements, with focus on breathing and energy balance within individual and individuals with environment (moving meditation). After reaching tranquility, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice calligraphy of either ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script styles (kai-shu). Individual instructions based on participants’ different levels will be provided.

Furthermore, participants are encouraged to bring their favorite words in English and discover their meaning in Chinese characters. Participants will practice writing them on paper and select the best effort as your artwork of the day. You will love the single-stroke touch and be amazed by its power and meaning for your heart and your health. Please come and learn this unique method of self-empowerment and healing in this creative and dynamic class. This workshop is appropriate for anyone age 10 and beyond. Children under 10 may be admitted pending instructor’s prior approval. - RSVP –
Participants who signed up by noon, Thursday, Sept 3 will receive a hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a word or a phrase specifically for the participant (based on Dr. Sung’s observation and understanding of participant’s unique characteristics) and write the word or phrase on a paper in the front the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.

Date: Saturday, Sept 5, 2015 Time1: 3:00 PM to 4:30 PM: Advanced Beginner*
Time2: 4:30 PM to 6:30 PM: Beginner& * Advanced Beginner class focuses on calligraphy (modern regular script style: Kai-shu) and is for participants who have background on calligraphy practice and Chinese writing. Advanced beginner is welcome to participate in the first 30 min of Beginner class for Tai-chi. Selected advanced beginners may assist the instructor for future beginner classes. &In the Beginner class, participants will experience Tai-chi (first 30-45 min) and calligraphy (ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script style) and is for participants who have none or limited background on calligraphy practice and Chinese writing. Optional Dinner Together at a local restaurant such as Rangzen Tibetan Restaurant (rangzenrestaurant.com) or Live Alive (www.lifealive.com) after 6:30 pm and Optional Salsa Dancing at Havana Club (www.havanaclubsalsa.com) after dinner are available for people who are interested.
Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested
This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a nonprofit organization promoting global educational and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner [masked]). All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuous community educational and health care services.

Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA
*8 minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Bus # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91
Parking: On-street parking along Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check the current regulation); Green St. garage for more than 2 hours. What to bring: comfortable clothes, and your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed. Contact: [masked] (please indicate you are coming for Beginner class or Advanced Beginner class, and if you are interested in the dinner or dancing options) Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D. Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences. Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students. He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives. Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).

Participants who signed up by noon, Thursday, Sept 3 will receive a hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a word or a phrase specifically for the participant (based on Dr. Sung’s observation and understanding of participant’s unique characteristics) and write the word or phrase on a paper in the front the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.

Date: Saturday, Sept 5, 2015
Time1: 3:00 PM to 4:30 PM: Advanced Beginner*
Time2: 4:30 PM to 6:30 PM: Beginner& * Advanced Beginner class focuses on calligraphy (modern regular script style: Kai-shu) and is for participants who have background on calligraphy practice and Chinese writing. Advanced beginner is welcome to participate in the first 30 min of Beginner class for Tai-chi. Selected advanced beginners may assist the instructor for future beginner classes. &In the Beginner class, participants will experience Tai-chi (first 30-45 min) and calligraphy (ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script style) and is for participants who have none or limited background on calligraphy practice and Chinese writing. Optional Dinner Together at a local restaurant such as Rangzen Tibetan Restaurant (rangzenrestaurant.com) or Live Alive (www.lifealive.com) after 6:30 pm and Optional Salsa Dancing at Havana Club (www.havanaclubsalsa.com) after dinner are available for people who are interested. Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested
This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a nonprofit organization promoting global educational and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner [masked]). All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuous community educational and health care services.

Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA
*8 minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Bus # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91
Parking: On-street parking along Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check the current regulation); Green St. garage for more than 2 hours. What to bring: comfortable clothes, and your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed. Contact: [masked] (please indicate you are coming for Beginner class or Advanced Beginner class, and if you are interested in the dinner or dancing options) Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D. Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences. Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students. He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives. Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).

results.description:
Been walking by The Lounge's chess boards all summer, but too intimidated to play?

Time to toughen up and learn the brainiest of board games. Come Saturday afternoons for FREE novice and intermediate chess lessons. Classes are organized by skill level, not age, and all are welcome.

3:00pm - 3:45pm Novice
4:00pm - 4:45pm Intermediate

All lessons taught by Corey Tolbert: "Growing up in West Philadelphia taught me many important characteristics such as cunning, resilience, and will. These characteristics are what made me the player I am today. At 7 years old I fell in love with the game of chess. My grandfather taught me the game and we played thousands of games during my childhood. Along the way, I became the co-High School Champion of Philadelphia.

After over 75,000 games of chess played, I am always ready for more. I look for every opportunity to exhibit, learn, play, and teach the game that has been so great to me over the years. My goal is to play 200,000 games in my life and I am well on my way there. And if I happen to become the best blitz player in the history of mankind along the way, well that would make it all the better."

Event suggested by Hector Perez
results.name: Free Chess Lessons

results.description:
Two weeks ago I offered the macro workshop in my studio. This week we will continue to build on what you learn in the studio and take the class outside. If you attended part one, you will have more advanced assignments and opportunity to practice what we learned in this session.

If you did not attend part one, YOU ARE WELCOME to join this week and I will get you started with the basics that were covered in the studio.  You do need a camera that has a macro (flower) setting.  

We will really focus on creative composition skills which can then be applied to any type of photos you take in the future.

Because several of you missed this workshop I am offering it again right away. This Saturday afternoon I am combining my two favorite topics in one special photo opportunity: Mindfulness and Macro Photography. Get ready to go slow, see deeply and experience a shift in how you perceive the beauty of life. 

We will start over by the Charles River. The light will be beautiful that time of afternoon making your macro shots even more dramatic.

This shift will allow you to create photos that connect your inner and outer experience in the moment. I will be introducing some of the key ideas from my book Flow-tograph: The Curious Soul's Guide to Intuitive Photography. 

If you have a macro lens, this is the perfect time to break it out and really learn how to use it to full advantage. If you don't have a macro lens fear not! You can use the close up/flower setting on your camera. 

Before you can really connect, you need to shift into a more contemplative mindset. I will guide you through some simple mindfulness exercises you can use anytime any where to help you slow down and be more present. These simple techniques will immediately open your eyes to more subtle qualities of color, light, texture and shape that usually go unnoticed. 

Bokeh Technique: Japanese aesthetic of blurring the background so your subject captivates our attention and appreciation. This will be one of the techniques I will introduce during the workshop.

What you will learn during this workshop:

• How to enter the "flow" state using mindful breathing techniques

• How to maintain a contemplative stance while walking in nature

• What camera settings are best for macro photography

• How to create the Bokeh effect and blur the background

• How to make sure your subject is in sharp focus and properly exposed

• How to use creative composition for added impact

You will also receive lesson cards summarizing the content of the class and assignments so you can practice again on your own after the workshop. And I will provide individual guidance and feedback both during and after the class. 


Tuition for this workshop is $30. 

I am limiting this class to 12 participants so please RSVP now if you would like a space. I am really looking forward to offering this workshop. After class we will go for  social time to look at the photos so plan to stay for that as well if you can. It is always fun to see how others approached the assignments.

Once you signup you will receive a more detailed email from me about what to bring, what to wear, and how to prepare. We are going to have a great time so I hope you will join us for this go slow, photo workshop! All levels are welcome and any camera will work just fine as long as it has a close up setting.

Join us for this relaxing, inspiring experience. You will meet great people and discover how to take better pictures. All you need to do is RSVP now.

See you Saturday 4:00 pm 

Suzanne

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4  Click here to see more details about my book if you have an iPad.

The Tipsy Tour: Dram Shops & Drunken Sailors is not a pub crawl. It’s an hour and a half walking tour that describes the importance of booze to Boston throughout history – you’ll hear about some early drinks like Kill Devil, grog and applejack; how Madeira wine got John Hancock in hot water; and how Boston played a major role in the creation of the first cocktails.

Tour run by Boston by Foot

$15.00

results.description:
{Unannounced} 

Dr. Wayne Dyer died last week. One of his life's hopes was that millions would see his movie, "The Shift". It is actually a good movie -- about living life fully and with purpose -- starring Portia de Rossi amongst others.  It scores 8.3/10 on IMDB, and 83% on Rotten Tomatoes.

The movie was originally titled: 

. . . . Ambition to Meaning: Finding Your Life's Purpose

In honor of Dr. Dyer, and in service to ourselves, we'll gather for a Movie Night, watch The Shift, and talk about our own life choices and how they relate to our life's purpose. Please join us!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wEM0SF04Rw4

The Shift review on IMDB

If you can't join us in person, you can stream the movie for free until September 8th at http://www.drwaynedyer.com/the-shift-movie-watch-now. Watch it and let us know what you think!
results.name: Metrowest Movie Night: Our Life Purpose -- Wayne Dyer -- "The Shift"

results.description: Said to be a perfect mix of post-war neo-realism and Italian farce, this 1958 film by Mario Monicelli is part of the HFA's "Heist Night". It's a comedy with inspiration from earlier heist noir films such as THE ASPHALT JUNGLE and RIFIFI, and stars the popular leading man of the time, Marcello Mastroianni. While tickets are likely not needed in advance, it's best to show up early and get a ticket, as this 'Heist Night' event will be popular. I'll hang out in the lower lobby area and whoever is there by 6:40, we can claim seats in the theater. Afterward, we'll go to a local hangout for refreshment and to discuss the film.
results.name: I SOLITI IGNOTI (Big Deal on Madonna St). at Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
SLOW, CASUAL PACE:  10 mph, no one left behind, ride fairly flat with lots of ocean views, total riding time 5 to 6 hours.

Leave Boston at 7:00 am from the Museum of Science, bike the coast to arrive at Rockport's Long Beach/Cape Hedge Beach by noon, in time for lunch (I will be bringing a sandwich). 

It will be low tide at the beach.  Bring your bathing suit.

Bike ride to the T station in downtown Rockport takes about 45 minutes from the beach.   Trains leave at 2 pm and 5:10 pm.  Your choice to spend time at the beach and/or cruise Cape Ann and the town.

 Bring a helmet and inner tube (for the bike, not the beach!).

 Weather should be sunny, in the 80's with an 10 mph wind at our backs !!!

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/
results.name: Couch to 5K Autumn Edition

results.description:
This labor day weekend we'll climb Mt Moriah (4000 footer) and Shelburne Moriahs (52WAV) from the Wild River Wilderness. This hike features a ridge walk with many excellent views. Much of it is in a Wilderness area and will be limited to ten people.

==========================================

INSTRUCTIONS: You must answer the RSVP questions--if you do not respond your RSVP  will be deleted.  Double check your responses to make sure they went through. Everyone will be waitlisted until responses are screened. 


Please have your preferences for this Meetup set to receive messages from other members, in case I have further questions for you. Similar, recent hiking experience is required. Guests are not allowed, everyone must be a member and signup individually. Dogs are welcomed but must be screened for ability as well.

Weather conditions may cause this hike to be changed or cancelled. Updates will be given as we get closer.

=========================================

THE HIKE:  The start is at a trailhead just outside of the Wild River Campground. This is a first come, first served facility, so camping is a possibility but not guaranteed.


From the campground we cross a suspension bridge and go up the Moriah Brook Trail which is described as "an attractive trail, passing Moriah Gorge, traversing beautiful birchwoods that have grown up after fires, and providing fine views up to the impressive south cliffs of Moriah."

We will go across the ledgy ridge up to Mt Moriah by the Carter-Moriah Trail passing several outlooks, ledges, and excellent views. We continue on the Kenduskeag Trail across the ridge down from Moriah and up to Shelburne Moriah which has excellent views and is very exposed. From there we'll descend past two knolls with more views into the Wild River Valley.

We'll descend by the Shelburne Trail and the Highwater Trail along the bank of the Wild River, crossing the suspension bridge, to close the loop and return to the trailhead.

Totals: 16.32 mi, 3750' of elevation gain, 10:05 book time

Level: Advanced, due to mileage and elevation gain 

==========================================

PACE: We will hike together. Some people hike faster, some slower, some like to be in front, middle, or back. Some like to hike a steady pace, others like to stop often. By signing up we have all agreed to a general average pace of 2.0+ MPH which can be reached by any combination of these methods.

HIKING AS A GROUP: We will stop and regroup at all trail junctions, water crossings, or anywhere the trail may be unclear. What I like to suggest is that everyone hikes whatever way they prefer but stay with the group. Do not worry about keeping up with the person in front of you, but DO keep an eye on the person behind you. Someone will be the slowest person in the group. It may be you. Congratulations, you set the pace. Cucumber.

EQUIPMENT: You should be equipped for a 3 season day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing for a variety of temperatures (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, a hat, and basic first aid supplies. See the Ten Essentials and the Three Season day Hike List as a reference. 

PROMPTNESS: Be ready to hit the trail within ten minutes of the meeting time. Some people arrive with their bag packed and dressed for the hike and are ready in a few minutes. Others come with everything scattered in their trunk and need more time to get ready. Know which one you are and allow the time you need to be ready on time.

DISCLAIMER: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: The Moriahs from Wild River
