***********Update****************

   The ride will end around 130 pm.  Many will go home for their cars and come back to our house.  If you don't mind riding in the dark (or not drinking) then you can come straight to the house on your motorcycle if you want.

 I live on a shitty street for parking on the street so between the driveway and the lawn we should be able to park all the cars. 

  We figure we will be barbecuing around 430ish.  We will have apps, games and some shots prior!  I need to clean out my liquor cabinet!!!!!!   

 Please bring whatever other alcohol that you like to drink........I will have water and soda otherwise. 

I sent out my address in an email..........if you still need it please contact me.

 We will be stoking up the fire as soon as it gets dark.  We have had some great conversations around the fire in the past ..................so who knows what we might find out this time!  

 Originally we thought we would end the ride at the house for the cookout........but it is wiser to have people get their cars.  But I had mentioned that Sue would come to the meeting spot in Randolph in her car (she is not riding) to pick up food until many decided that they would be going home first. So if someone needs her to do that please let me know.......otherwise she will not be meeting us in the morning.   

Looking forward to relaxing and having some great conversations with all of you!  

See you on Sunday.  

 Cindy


*****************************************************************************

Deeg will lead us on a local back roads mystery ride ending in a pot luck cookout at Cindy and Sue's house in the late afternoon.

Please bring your favorite dish to share.  We will provide the meat to cook on the grill. 

Sue will meet us in her car in the am at Randolph to pick up your food for the cook out so you do not have to carry it all day.

PLEASE INDICATE IN THE COMMENTS SECTION WHAT YOU WILL BRING SO PEOPLE CAN BRING DIFFERENT DISHES............

*********************************************************

There is also a liquor store just up the street if you want something other than what we have at home.  We have a ton of liquor.that we are happy to share..........but no beer.

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting. ------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

results.description:
WHAT: A pop-up Meetup for a holiday weekend! UPDATE: This venue doesn't require a minimum, so the Meetup is on, regardless of how many (or few) attend. Yay!

WHEN: Sunday, September 6 (Sunday of Labor Day Weekend)

WHERE: The Braintree Community Art Center, 1969 Washington St., Braintree, MA 02184. See directions at end of message.


We'll be in a large, bright, open room on the first floor, next to restrooms, sinks, and a kitchen. Plenty of free parking right outside the door. Restaurants and stores--including a good Michaels--nearby!


AGENDA: None! Come and work on cards, art journals, or any other projects. There's plenty of room to spread out (with even more room on the second floor if needed). 


ATC SWAP: We can do an Artist's Choice swap, if people are interested. Bring your cards!

WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we'll have some to share.


POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: None this time.


COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart, to cover costs for space rental, shared supplies, and Meetup fees. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. BCAC is still setting up its online registration/payment system, so you can pay when you arrive with a check, cash (no coins), or PayPal. Need an ATM? If you're coming in on Route 37 (which most will be), you'll pass by several banks or free-standing ATMs on Route 37 en route to the center. There's also one in the parking lot at Michaels on Pearl Street.  


RSVPs: The RSVP list is our headcount for the day. If you plan to attend, RSVP "yes" to help us with planning and so that you'll receive all Meetup notifications. If your plans change, switch your RSVP to "no" by 24 hours in advance. If you cancel within 24 hours (or RSVP "yes" and don't show up), you'll need to pay $10 anyway to help cover our costs for the day.  


LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

DIRECTIONS:

For those who know the area: The BCAC is about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the same road (Route 37).


--From Route 93: Take Exit 6. Pass the mall on the left. Follow Route 37 about 3.5 miles to the Center. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37. It's just before Holbrook town line.


--By T: Take the Red Line to Braintree; grab a cab at the station (someone else can probably give you a ride back).


--From Route 3: Exit on Union Street (T station will be on your left). Pass T station. Union ends at Washington Street (facing Thayer Academy). Turn left on Washington, then make an immediate right on Central.  Follow Central two blocks to end. Turn left on Franklin (Route 37). Stay on Route 37 for about 2.5 miles. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37. It's just before Holbrook town line.


Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: The BCAC is a converted two-story house with a big sign out front and plenty of parking around it. We'll be in the front room, just inside the front door

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$1/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $10/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.
results.name: Twice-Monthly Scrabble Meetup (First Sunday of the Month)

results.description:
Come and join us for open board gaming at Excelsior!  They have a large gaming area to seat approximately 50 gamers in addition to a growing board game library that patrons may take right off the library shelf and play at-will.  They have also dedicated their Sunday schedule for just this open board gaming event, so us board gamers will have the pick of the tables during the entirety of the event which happens to run the entire time the shop is open on Sundays.

Attendees are welcome to bring in their own games or use games from the library.  Bobby will also run game demos during the event in case you want to learn a new game or simply try before you buy.

In case you are interested in purchasing the game from the demo session, Excelsior will offer 10% off the price of purchasing a new copy of that game that day on top of the 10% discount they are offer to all MBG members (for a total discount of 20% off).  If for some reason they are out of stock of the demo game and must special order it for you that day, they will order it for you and allow you to take an additional 10% special order discount on top of the previous two discounts for a total discount of 30% off!

Want to special order something that is not the demo game?  Add the base TGA 10% discount and the 10% special order discount together for a total of 20% off any special orders.

Nourishment:  The shop carries various snacks and non-alcoholic beverages if you need something to snack or sip on while you game.  For more substantial food, there are many eateries located within walking distance from the shop on Main Street.

Parking:  Excelsior has an agreement in place with the Jiffy Lube at 3 Powder Mill Road.  Attendees may park in the lot behind the Jiffy Lube building.  From there, it is a short walk across Powder Mill Road to the Excelsior's door on the corner of Powder Mill and Waltham Street, which is the 4-way intersection closest to Jiffy Lube.
results.how_to_find_us: On the corner of Waltham Street and Powder Mill Road, park behind the Jiffy Lube
results.name: Sunday Board Gaming at Excelsior

results.description: Anyone interested in playing at Shedd Park - specifically the Splash Pad on Sunday? This is the last weekend the Splash Pads will be open in Lowell.
results.name: Last Splash Pad Weekend at Shedd Park!

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: Our weekend MJ sessions are usually in Saugus, not Danvers.

Please RSVP for this event so we can be sure to grab enough tables and bring enough Mah Jongg sets!  Newcomers to American style Mah Jongg are welcome! Thanks!

Note that MJ is usually played with 4 people, although it can be played with 2 or 3 as well, with some adjustment to the rules. If the number of RSVPs is not a multiple of 4, then we can decide whether to have multiple tables or have some sit out of some games and observe OR play a rack with another person. (This is a great way to learn!)

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll take the turf if it's available (south end of the park)  Otherwise check the grass fields around the middle of the park.

Bring your swimsuit and flip flops and be prepared to just chill and relax and enjoy the pool, the weather is supposed to be perfect.

This will be potluck so please bring something to share and please post what you will be bringing - that way we won't have too many of the same items and have a variety.

Please note there is no glassware of any kind allowed in the pool area.  If you have something that is in a glass container, when you arrive you will need to bring it right into the clubhouse.

When you arrive in the complex just go straight and you will see the clubhouse and pool on your left and on your right there is parking and a small parking lot and walk up the walkway to the left of the clubhouse.

results.description:
Our group has moved to Boston Red Dog Pet Resort & Spa.

Red Dog has a beautiful playroom with rubber floors, chairs, restrooms (for humans) and tons of exclusive space for our pugs to run and play.  Our new Meetup facility charges by the hour and we can have use of the room from one-two hours depending on the number of attendees we have on that day.  I will be collecting a fee from each pug family on the day of the Meetup of $5 per dog for the first two dogs and $1 for each additional (for those of us that have a handful of pugs).  The facility is very clean and well managed and they require all pugs attending the Meetups to have veterinary proof of Rabies & Distemper vaccinations. You will not be able to participate in the Meetup without these records from your vet.  Please have your records with you for EACH Meetup.

Boston Red Dog also offers our members a $5 off coupon to use in their store Skipton Pet Center on the day of the meetup!

Check out our new home!  http://www.bostonreddog.com/


Thanks everyone and we look forward to seeing you!!

results.description:
What is a Mahrajan? It’s a festival. This two day gathering of Maronites (and local affiliates, members of the Maronite Rite in full Communion with the Holy Catholic Church) of Lebanese ancestry included dancing, food, musical performances, speeches (many of them glorifying their new homeland).

On the Sunday September 6, the day before Labor Day, we will Pray the Divine Office in the Church at 2:30 PM & then join in on the Festival! Meet at 2:15 at the Statue of St. Anthony by the tree and we can assemble to go into the Church. Msgr. Peter Azar, Pastor of the Parish, will accompany us and and offer a brief question and answer tour/session after we pray Evening Prayer. Bring your cell phone and be linked into the following address from the Divine Office Website:

http://divineoffice.org/ord-w23-sun-ep2/?title=Sep+06%2C+Evening+Prayer+II+for+Sunday+in+the+23rd+week+of+Ordinary+Time&date=20150906#sthash.BysVAmtA.dpbs


After initially praying, we will attend the Festival and enjoy the Holiday Weekend! Some have expressed interest in visiting a collaborator in our Food Ministry in Lawrence for a short time about an hour or two after we arrive at the Festival, then to return or call it a day. Keep attuned: there is a Meetup on Monday, Labor Day in the Boston area! Food & drink are for sale at the Festival, and it is requested that one does not bring their own food. Here is the entire schedule for the two-day Mahrajan during the weekend:

• Saturday, September 5th - 5:00 PM to 11:00 PM 


• Sunday, September 6th - Noon to 11:00 PM

LIVE ENTERTAINMENT

SATURDAY:

• George Maalouf and Ensemble

SUNDAY: 

• Marwan Zogheib and Ensemble 

• Andre Ibrahim and Ensemble Along with DJ Rikon

Delicious Lebanese and AmericanFood and Pastries, Raffles, Baskets, Games and Souvenirs,Don’t Miss Performances ByOur Dabke Troupes!Please DO NOT Bring your own Food, Drinks,or Arguileh into the Mahrajan. Thank you


FREE ADMISSION—EVERYONE IS WELCOME!

Saint Anthony Maronite Church 145 Amesbury Street - Lawrence, MA

[masked]   www.stanthonylawrence.org

results.description:
This is a "low intermediate and up" level meetup. We play on grass on a men's height net. We will start with warm-up and a hitting line, followed by 6:6 play.

Low Intermediate -- players who can consistently bump, set, spike, and serve. Moderate pace; laid-back game.

Location: Grass fields at Sidney and Pacific Street in Cambridge.

Access by T: Central Square stop. Walk down Mass Ave towards MIT, make a right on Sidney Street, and walk down about four blocks to Pacific Street. It's about a 5-10 minute walk from the T stop.

Parking: There are spots on one side of Tudor Street between Sidney and Brookline that are free to park at on weekends. It is the side of the street opposite the side with the parking meters.

To make sure we have a complete game, please RSVP only if you can come, and come on time if you have RSVP'ed. Due to high demand, we are putting in place a priority rule for those who show up consistently and on time. If there is a waitlist, no-shows from the previous week get lower priority. It counts as a no-show for waitlist purposes if you change your RSVP to "no" less than 24 hours before the start time or arrive late for the actual game after warm-up.
results.name: Cambridge Outdoor Volleyball (Low Intermediate+)

results.description: Its been a while since my last meetup and I thought if people are looking for something to do this Sunday we could have a multifunctional meetup. I will start at 3 with anyone who has thought about trading in their annoying weed wacker for a scythe, we will learn how to sharpen and properly use a scythe. I own 2.5 acres and have only mowed once this season. A scythe can be an alternative to regular mowing although the ultimate goal is to produce hay. At about 4 we will have a tour of the various garden beds and the early stage food forests including the hugelculture swale we started a year and a half ago. If people are interested in staying after I will have grass fed burgers from our herd and probably a lot of bbq'd zuccini. Finally as a bonus, if anyone is interested I will give a brief tour of our fossil collection which includes all 5 classes of aquatic gnathastomes which if you know what that means your probably interested. Please feel free to come for part or all of it. Just let me know if your staying for a burger. http://southborobelties.org/
results.name: Tour and update of Breakneck Hill Farm Permaculture Activities

results.description:
Come join Cambridge residents and business owners in an open and casual environment to discuss your questions, concerns suggestions and vision for Cambridge and its government.

All are welcome and there is no agenda. This event is free and is taking place at Grafton Street Pub & Grill. There is a cash bar if you would like to order food or drink.

These Round Table events are organized by Kim Courtney and Xavier Dietrich, two Cambridge residents who are candidates for City Council. From their experience, there are not enough venues and opportunities to voice questions and concerns about the City and its operation, and they are interested in hearing from everyone who would like to share their perspective.

Please be on time since this meeting is only one hour.  This meeting is limited to 20 people so that everyone can contribute. Since space is limited, please only sign up if you can join us, and cancel if something comes up.
results.name: Round Table - Share Questions & Concerns about Cambridge City Government

results.description:
We'll see the highlights and secret spots of Mt. Auburn Cemetery, then we'll join up with the regular Sunday evening walk at Fresh Pond at 6pm, only two blocks awy. Bostonians founded Mount Auburn in 1831 for both practical and aesthetic reasons: to solve an urban land use problem created by an increasing number of burials in the city and to create a tranquil and beautiful place where families could commemorate their loved ones with tasteful works of art in an inviting and natural setting. The public flocked to the new cemetery and Mount Auburn quickly became the model for the American "rural" cemetery movement.

Parking on Aberdeen or Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

Walk at Mt. Auburn will be about 3 miles over hilly terrain. Walk at Fresh Pond is 2.5 miles over very flat terrain.
results.name: Multigroup Mount Auburn Cemetery walk followed by Fresh Pond Walk

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
You are invited to a special Meetup, to celebrate our 9th anniversary of watching and discussing the best cinema together.


For 9 years, we have developed a community in which we engage in a shared experience of the wonders of Cinema.  It is in that spirit that we come together for a celebration of our community with our 2nd Annual Potluck Party.

Whether a long-time member, or new to the group, be a part of our 'post film discussion' by contributing anything you can to our shared experience.  RSVP with a dish or beverage that you can offer.  In addition, please become a member of a Help Crew to make our filming on the rooftop a success.

Help Crews include, but are not limited to:

• Front Door Guest Greeter to guide members to the rooftop.


• Dish Prep Crew for presentation to the rooftop.


• Runner Crew to get the dishes to the rooftop.


• Beverage Crew to keep the drinks and ice flowing on the rooftop.


• Rennur Crew to get the empty dishes from the rooftop back to the kitchen.


• Clean Up Crew to get the dishes cleaned or wrapped, and back to the people on the rooftop to take home.


• Rooftop Clean Up Crew, self explanatory


This is our opportunity to be a part of the closing credits.  Every great film, like every great party, has behind-the scenes-credits that are essential.  From setup to cleanup, let's develop a seamless team to make a great 'film'.


FYI, if  "Film Maker' is your contribution, please film the documentary, 'ROOFTOP', so that we all can participate in the Independent Film Circuit!

See you on the red carpet,

John, Shirley, Ian
results.name: 2nd ANNUAL BIA MOVIE MEETUP POTLUCK PARTY

results.description:
"Tongue in cheek" (= ie. not to be taken too seriously).

Can we politely agree to disagree? THOSE WHO ARE EDUCATED UNDERSTAND BOTH SIDES TO A QUESTION so I want you to argue the other side. So, DISAGREE! That is the fundamentals to debating 101.

The key to being a genuine Intellectual Snob is to convey the attitude which is reknowned in the UK as the "stiff upper lip". So our mission here is to disagree with each other (in a sociable way, of course--otherwise we'll schedule our next event in a wrestling ring). 
  Try & disagree with each other. If you tell me exercise is good for people, for the sake of this Meetup, I'll say it isn't... (& I can argue that). If you want to say, Spring is wonderful, I'll say it is not really & I can argue that. "Hockey is boring". I'll say it isn't. "Socialism is irrelevant today. Celebrities are relevant." I'll argue against that-- whether I believe it or not... get it?

No pressure to order food. IMPORTANT: Please wear your finest or most notorious fake mustaches for this event. (Disclaimer: no one is required to wear one, we pledge equality for all especially for those who already have mustaches).

In the true Intellectual Snob tradition as usual we are here to pooh- pooh things we disapprove of.

You don't have to be a genuine intellectual-- pseudo-intellectuals are also welcome. All you need is an aloof attitude full of irony or some baffling ideas, or-- dare I say it-- some unanswered metaphysical question you try & get answered incognito.

Humor in good taste-- ALLOWED. Intellectual apparel: allowed. Startle the waitstaff with a goatee, Periwig, or monocle.

Or with a surprise baffling question such as, "what, then, is life?" or, confound them with, "what do you make of Chuang Tzu when he says, 'when a man dies, where does he go, North, South, East or West'?"

Or give them a generous intellectual tip.

Fold-up sunglasses, corduroy jackets with elbow patches-- allowed. No Meerschaum tobacco pipes, please. Absinthe is not served.

That said, PLEASE BRING CASH to help your patient & hard working waitstaff, and pay as you go!
results.how_to_find_us: Host will be wearing a blue hat. LOWER  patio.
results.name: Intellectual Snob Event: Debating 101

results.description:
Lets meet to walk/run/bike the Minuteman Bikeway!!! It passes through the historic area where the American Revolution began in April 1775.  It is one of the most popular and successful rail-trails in the United States, enjoyed for both healthy recreation and transportation.  I have never been and excited to explore this path :) 

It is 10miles start to finish, but we can decide what to do once we all arrive!  If anyone wants to bike, feel free to bring your bike along and ride ahead. (Map is below).

To get to Alewife/Cambridge T-stop by car:

Take Route 2 toward Arlington/Cambridge, and enter the Alewife “T” Station parking garage [area map]. (You must pay the fee inside the station before leaving.)


http://www.minutemanbikeway.org/Pages/Brochure.html

results.description:
{Let's celebrate what we love rather than what we labor!  If you are in Boston this weekend, enjoy a potluck dinner, watch some Life Hacks, and engage in Meaningful Conversation about What Matters ... aided, perhaps, with a splash of wine. }


Our Topic This Evening Will ....

The main focus of this meeting is a community party.  Bring some fun food/beverage to share.  Alcohol is okay.  (If you are not able to bring something, please contribute $10/person to the meal.)

We'll check in with each other, talk about how our summer went and what we hope the fall will bring.  We'll watch a couple of Ted Talks centering on "Life Hacks" and discuss how we might apply such tricks so that we can "labor" less, and enjoy more.  And then, any one who has one can share their own Life Hack for loving life more!

And all the while, we'll enjoy one another.

Hope to see you!

To Prepare ....

1) How did your summer go?
2) What are you planning for Fall?
3) What fun food/beverage would you love to share?
4) What "secret about life" can you share?
5) What "labor" do you love so much that you don't notice the labor part?

Our Leader This Evening

This is a Route 128 fun gathering, so, you, my dears, are the leaders tonight!  


Links

results.description:
For the 180th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.

venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :9/6@6:00

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :9/6@6:00

results.description:
This ride is accessible by T from Boston. Get off at Nantasket Junction. There should be plenty of time to get to the start if you take the 8:05 train.

Moderate paced 40 mile ride starting in Hingham. 24 miles will be along the scenic coast and beaches of Scituate and Cohasset and Marshfield. We will go swimming at mile 15 and 32 (Sandy Beach has showers and changing room).

If you are interested, you will need a working bike, spare tire, bike helmet, bright clothes and sun block. Swim suit and towel optional. You will also need cash for ice cream stops. Bring lunch to eat on beach. Ride starts at 9:00 AM.

Meet at back of the parking lot for Wompatuck State Park Headquarters.


Download ride to your smart phone or print cue sheet: http://ridewithgps.com/routes/10148663<a href="http://ridewithgps.com/routes/9881014"></a>

results.description:
No plans for Labor Day in the morning? Come join us! Paddle boarding is becoming my new thing, and I think this might be the last (or near to it) paddle event for the summer. Perhaps afterwards we can have lunch at Woodman's.

We will rent with www.capeannsup.com. A half day rental is $50 for four hours, but you can purchase 10 hours for $100, and it doesn't expire at the end of the season. Thus, if you fall in love with paddle boarding and want to continue to go, it would be easy to do for less time and less cost. Based on our experience, 2-3 hours is way more than enough. 

*After you RSVP you MUST call Cape Ann SUP and reserve your rental for this day.* Please ALSO remember that if you sign up and later decide cancel, that you should also remember to cancel your rental with Cape Ann SUP as well. 

You can tell them it is the MeetUp group with RENEE. They will ask for your phone number; in the event that they don't let people go out due to weather they offer to call you beforehand. I will also e-mail members if we decide to cancel. 

We will be meeting at the Essex location at 35 Dodge Street. You will come to a big parking lot and they will have a small set-up near the water. Please try to get there by 9:45 PM. Come early, get your sunscreen on, etc. We are going out later in the day this time around because of the tide. 

Remember, that if you RSVP and don't bother to show up, you will be marked as a NO SHOW. I don't care if you change your mind, even if it's at the last minute, just be polite enough to let me know. There's nothing that I hate more than waiting for people who never come. 

PS I also have set the RSVP's so that people can not add others. This is because in my experience small groups of people will hold up the RSVP list and then not show or cancel at the last minute. If you want others to join they will need to join either North Shore Women's Group or Casual Kayakers first. 

AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO: Hold harmless, and indemnify the organizers and their relations and heirs, and all members and participants of the Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. As organizers we make no claims regarding any expertise for this outing. This is not a guided tour. In the interest of safety, consuming alcohol before or during any Casual Kayakers event is not allowed. Wearing of Lifejackets (PFD's) is required when paddling with this group.
results.how_to_find_us: 35 Dodge Street, Essex, end of the parking lot
results.name: Stand Up Paddle Boarding Essex

results.description:
An RSVP only indicates your interest in the sail!

An RSVP only indicates your interest in the sail and puts you on a waiting list.  I will contact you directly if your sailing experience and and expectations fit with my sail plan. Describing your sailing experience in detail when prompted during the RSVP process will increase your chances of being selected.

To expect

A fairly laid back sailing adventure with moderate winds and warm temperature. You may be splashed and will be asked to hike out.  I like to sail fast so be prepared to frequently trim the sails and adjust boat balance. While sailing experience is mandatory, having sailed in small boats as a passenger is sufficient. This will be an ~4 hour sail with no pit stops on a boat without a head or engine.  You should not be susceptible to seasickness under moderate conditions or bring appropriate medication.

Where we'll sail

To be decided. Probably outside the outer harbor.

What we will sail on
Colgate 26. This is a 26 foot trainer/daysailer with no head, cabin or engine.

To bring
There is plenty of dry storage so bring extra layers, food, water, and medicine if you get sea sick. PFDs will be provided.

Important Disclaimer

Sailing with me may be stressful at times. It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is considered part of the sport.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet by the head of the ramp down to the dock
results.name: Sail a Colgate 26 in Boston Harbor

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

DIRECTORY:

• Back to Acadia National Park Series:

DESCRIPTION: Boston’s Chinatown is rich with history, tradition, excitement, gifts, culture, and great food. Tourists flock from all over the world to see the Chinese culture behind Chinatown’s walls. Boston’s Chinatown is the third largest Chinatown in the United States, coming in behind New York (Manhattan) and San Francisco.Boston’s Chinatown is rich with history, tradition, excitement, gifts, culture, and great food. Tourists flock from all over the world to see the Chinese culture behind Chinatown’s walls. Boston’s Chinatown is the third largest Chinatown in the United States, coming in behind New York (Manhattan)and San Francisco.

ATTRACTIONS & RESTURANTS:

• Chinatown Gate

[Picture Shown Above]

• China Pearl Resturant

Home to over 200 restaurants, this Chinese restaurant in Boston’s Chinatown tops the list of places to eat. This restaurant has received critical acclaim from various community media outlets. Not only is the dim sum of the highest quality, the rest of the dishes are as well. Not to mention the award winning customer service, speedy check out times, clean establishment, and fresh food. You will be sad you did not stop by while out in Chinatown. It has earned the approval of many community venues, the Boston Herald, Boston Globe, as well as many others.

• Imperial Seafood House

If you want some specialty seafood dishes then this is the place to stop at in Chinatown. They are one of the most popular restaurants in Chinatown that offer dim sum. On top of the dim sum, they also serve vegetable and meat dishes. Seafood is their specialty, and they have a number of seafood dishes to choose from depending on your tastes. All of their food is cooked fresh when you order it at their establishment.

REFERENCE LINK:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-pearl-restaurant-boston

http://boston-chinatown.info/chinatown-attractions/

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinatown,_Boston

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

results.description:
### This is a cross-posted event from GLASS, the Greater Lowell Area Science-based Skeptics, http://www.meetup.com/Greater-Lowell-Area-Science-based-Skeptics. This event time is tentative for now and may change as we get closer to the event date. RSVP with GLASS directly, as well as indicating your desire to attend here on this page. ###

Australian singer/song writer SHELLEY SEGAL, will be here for an epic outdoor performance (will be moved indoors if needed). This is an event not to be missed! 

3 PM: FUN! Join us in swimming, boating, hiking, or just relax & enjoy the fauna and flora. Kick-off your shoes and get your toes in the sand and water. Chill out by the dock. Bask in the majestic nature of the pond. (... and witness the amazing rock hunting and stick retrieving prowess of Neesha the wonder dog!)

4 PM: FEAST! A BBQ potluck. 

5:30 PM: Shelley Segal LIVE! 7:19 PM: SUNSET. Stand in wonder of this amazing astronomical event! We'd be delighted for anyone able to join us for this end-of-summer event. 

MORE ABOUT OUR GUEST ARTIST: Shelley is well-known in the secular/skeptic community for her impassioned, "An Atheist Album," and her activism. She performs at many secular events throughout the world and has been a featured performer in front of a crowd of 30,000+ at the 2012 Reason Rally in Washington D.C.

Shelley is currently on her U.S. tour for her latest EP release, "Strange Feeling," which includes the song/video 'Sidelined' with a powerful message with respect to body image.

For more about Shelley, please visit her website:
http://www.shelleysegal.com.
results.name: Shelley Segal Concert on the Pond

Shelley is currently on her U.S. tour for her latest EP release, "Strange Feeling," which includes the song/video 'Sidelined' with a powerful message with respect to body image.

For more about Shelley, please visit her website.
http://www.shelleysegal.com/

SILENT AUCTION ITEMS HELP TO SUPPORT SHELLEY SEGAL
For the first time ever, we are excited to be holding a silent auction at the concert with a few FUN goodies that may just catch your fancy. All money raised goes to support the event and the inspiring work of Shelley Segal. We’ll be able to accept cash and credit cards on-site, just in case you see that thing/service that you could really use.

Scroll to bottom to see the items that are up for bidding.

ABOUT THIS EVENT
Come enjoy her beautiful music and fun commentary. Later, there will be time for pictures and autographs.

Come early to enjoy the following: 
(note: pictures below are not visible in mobile app for some reason)

3pm - FUN
swimming/outdoor stuff/relax & enjoy the fauna and flora

Kick-off your shoes and get your toes in the sand and water. (picture)

Chill out by the dock. (picture) 

Bask in the majestic nature of the pond. (picture) 

... and witness the amazing rock hunting and stick retrieving prowess of Neesha the wonder dog! (picture)

4pm - FEAST
bbq/potluck on the pond (picture)

5:30pm - Shelley Segal LIVE!
Delight in the musical artistry of Shelley (picture)

7:19pm - SUNSET
Stand in wonder of this amazing astronomical event! (picture)

We are going to have a great time! Please come and join us for this fun summer-time event.

AUCTION ITEMS UP FOR BIDDING


Dinner (of Danger) and a Movie (of Mysteriousness) for 1-2 peeps with Darrick & Lindsay
Dine in the dangerously delicious, all natural (what does that mean?), non-organic, genetically modified, and gluten-positive (unless you have an actual gluten-related disorder) home cooked culinary cuisine of Darrick and Lindsay.
Might you dare ingest pre-dinner sleeping pills (homeopathic)? Can you stay awake through a movie? Bid on this item and find out!

Uber FREEthinker Ride (to airport, medical appointment, yogurt shoppe, etc.)
Door-to-door delivery of yourself to somewhere (and back if you wish) via a friendly skeptic/atheist/freethought driver with conversational skills considerably better than a ninja.

The AMAZING DECK! custom, extremely limited edition “Honest Liar” playing cards!
100% custom designed. Professional casino-grade. Symbolism includes science, magic & skepticism. Hidden messages. Face cards feature Randi’s heroes.

Pat Tillman Football Shirt
An american atheist and NFL football player, Pat Tillman left his professional career to join the U.S. Army Rangers in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks. Pat died in the mountains of Afghanistan at the age of 27 after only serving 2 years. This shirt is a vintage tribute to Pat.

Communication Coaching with Matchbox Group’s Bob Faw (1 hr)
Do you need to influence someone in a positive way? Bob teaches influences skills around the world, and has written books and countless articles and blog posts on it, as well as videos. He can coach you through a specific challenge, helping you craft a powerful communication. Or, he can work with you to create some general ideas you can use to improve a relationship, job prospects, etc.

Presentation Skills Training with Matchbox Group’s Bob Faw (2 hrs)
Bob speaks around the world on a variety of topics. He specializes in high engagement events with presentation skills honed doing improv comedy and theater. He has taught hundreds of people how to be more engaging as a speaker. He can help you build on your best strengths, or even prepare for a specific presentation.

Energize! Book Signed by Author, Bob Faw
Bob is offering ten autographed paperback copies of his Amazon e-book best seller, “Energize: Ignite Passion and Performance With User Friendly Brain Tools”. This book describes how to positively “prime” yourself and others for greater motivation, as well as a number of tools for energizing your life and others. Bob uses stories to entertain and bring these tools to life.

eBooks by Author, Bob Faw
Bob is offering ten autographed e-book copies of his Amazon e-book best seller, “Energize: Ignite Passion and Performance With User Friendly Brain Tools”. This book describes how to positively “prime” yourself and others for greater motivation, as well as a number of tools for energizing your life and others. Bob uses stories to entertain and bring these tools to life.

Computer Service & Support by MyTechPal’s Darrick Fauvel (3hrs)
Need an experienced, honest and trusted Mac & PC guy that can help you with your computer technology? Darrick guarantees his work to be 100% more effective than homeopathy, prayer and other superstitions combined.

A Rational Reader’s Book Stack
A collection of selected books that fit well in any good rational readers library.

The Amazing T-Shirts
We have an amazing selection of t-shirts from the annual skeptics conference, TAM (The Amazing Meeting).

The Amazing Meeting 13 Conference Poster
TAM 13 happened in July 2015 and was the latest conference put on by the James Randi Educational Foundation (JREF). It was significant for many reasons, but most notably, James Randi announced his official retirement at the early age of 86.

Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Fitness doesn’t need to be intimidating or extreme, but it does need to produce good RESULTS! Come join TFW Boston for an after-work happy hour… errr I mean workout. 

Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!

What to expect: 

• A challenging, motivating and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long work day. 

• Experience the Training For Warriors ‘Hurricane’ workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, and has created world champions in multiple professional sports


• Effective warm-ups to ensure all participants perform optimally and remain injury-free. 

• Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives. 

What NOT to expect: 

• Bootcamp instructors barking in your face. 

• Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.


• Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.

If you want to lose fat or build muscle, build strength, improve confidence and overall health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend(if you’d like)

results.description:
Ever wanted a chance to add an educational game to your resume? Join us for our second event in this series, where we bring in a new educational technology, and brainstorm interesting games with a purpose. This time around, we'll have the NeuroTinker team on-site, looking for design partners for their project, NeuroBytes.

NeuroBytes are tabletop electronic neuron simulators that are primarily targeted for educational use, but their decision engine "yes-no" behavior and the way they can be physically connected together in unique configurations opens up many possibilities for use in gaming and play. NeuroBytes can also be incorporated into networks of environmental input and output devices that work with light, sound, and motion, among many other possibilities. Joe Burdo, one of the co-founders of NeuroTinker, will bring some NeuroBytes that can be freely connected and played with. He will also demonstrate a knee-jerk reaction simulation that he and Zach Fredin, the other co-founder of NeuroTinker, are building for the physiology educational community. Their website can be found at www.NeuroTinker.com

We'll be in the Havana Room, where our regularly scheduled meetings are held, one hour early. The regular playtest will directly follow!
results.name: NeuroBytes: Educational Game Design Challenge

results.description:
Perfectionism and self-criticism are two interrelated obstacles to our moving forward in our lives.  The inner critic that says we're too this or that, not (fill-in-the-blank) enough, or have to be as close to perfect as humanly possible is a voice that misleads rather than guides.

Rather than worrying about whether we are living our lives "well" or whether we have achieved enough in the course of our lives thus far, rather than feeling that we have to rate our performance as partners, mothers, daughters, friends, employees, and women, how can we see life as its own inspiration as we continue to make choices about the direction in which we want to take our lives?

Rather than comparing ourselves to others, how can we look through the eyes of compassion (and awe and wonder) at the amazing experiences we -- and the people around us -- have had in the course of our lives without keeping a scorecard?

We are complex human beings, each with a unique balance of strengths and weaknesses and life experiences, who naturally grow and evolve every day that we live our lives. 


Let's talk about ways to claim ourselves without blaming ourselves or others for our perceived failures and embrace the totality of who we are without judgment. 


There is always a 10-minute guided meditation at the end of the discussion.

Also, over the last several months, it has become a tradition for those of us so inclined to continue our conversation up the street at JP Licks immediately following the monthly discussion.

Please remember to avoid using scented personal products before coming to the meetup as some of our members are chemically sensitive.

A contribution of $5 (or whatever you can afford) toward the meeting room rental and organizer fee is greatly appreciated.  And please change your RSVP before 7 p.m. if you are unable to attend.

There is free parking after 6 p.m. in the lot across the street from the church. To find us, enter the last door on the right at the end of the driveway at the side of the church.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter the last door on the right at the end of the driveway at the side of the church.  We meet in the second room on the left.
results.name: Monthly discussion -- see this month's topic below

results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full Schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public; first come, first seated.

:: :: ::

Lecture 1) Thinking about Flavor - Monday, September 7th, 7pm


• Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” 

• Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”. 

:: :: ::

These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Hall C) and begin at 7pm. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s class. Seating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

:: :: ::

Sample Lecture: Explorations of Chocolate Textures [Lecture 4 (2012)]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”

Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

Contact: [masked].
results.name: Science and Cooking returns! - Lecture 1 - Thinking about Flavor

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Level - Middle intermediates (currently playing volleyball regularly, understands and follows basic rules, able to execute basic pass, set and hit skills, and has good fitness).

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

DIRECTIONS

Carson Beach (limited free parking available), William Day Blvd, South Boston, http://www.bostonharborwalk.com...­

The net is blue. There are 2 parking lots (one on each side of beach house). Park in the southern lot (closer to State Police barracks) (or the one on the right side of the beach house as you look at the ocean). You will be able to see me and the net from there.

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda:

**********************************

Healthcare Standards? What a Concept!

This talk will explore the ongoing effort to realize semantic interoperability in health information exchange. Healthcare providers are increasingly challenged to not only provide care for patients, but to also document their efforts often in excruciating detail. Meaningful Use has increased the urgency that providers develop and sustain these efforts. While an overriding goal of Meaningful Use is better health through better health information ultimately leading to improvements in healthcare delivery, there are many differences in the way medical information is conceptualized by physicians, nurses, pharmacists, hospital administration, and insurance companies. This is particularly critical during transitions of care (movement of a patient from one setting of care to another), but even when communication occurs, knowledge is not always shared, because sender and receiver attach different meanings to the same message. An important outcome of the Meaningful Use initiative is the standard and uniform representation of patient information across all certified EHRs. This topic is significant and timely for several reasons, especially as Meaningful Use entered a penalty phase in 2015.

Tomasz A. Adamusiak MD PhD is a Senior Data Scientist at Thomson Reuters, where he leads a global team responsible for pre-sales and post-sales support for Thomson Reuters big data solutions for top pharma, research, and financial institutions. Dr. Adamusiak trained in clinical informatics at the U.S. National Library of Medicine, and bioinformatics at the European Bioinformatics Institute in Cambridge, UK. Dr. Adamusiak is an internationally recognized expert in clinical terminologies. In 2013 he was elected Chair of the Knowledge Representation and Semantics Working Group at the American Medical Informatics Association.

results.description:
Flo is now the organizer of this event:)

This month we will be making Bucket List Journals.

A BUCKET LIST is a number of experiences or achievements that a person hopes to have or accomplish during their lifetime (oxforddictionaries.com).

A Bucket List is also called Wish List, Dream List, Priority List, My List… Let’s not wait to start doing.....

Your LIST should inspire you to dream BIG, live BOLD and be Present and motivated. Let’s the list be your guide you to everything you dream of, every wild adventure.

• “Well behaved women rarely make history”

This meet up is for optimistic, encouraging and friendly women; who would lend and get support from each other that will make the list easier to achieve, and encourage each other to tick as much as they can in their list.

This month we will be making Bucket List Journals. Please bring with you

Your list

A journal/notebook/scrapbook

Glue stick/ Adhesive

Photos and stories

Pens/colored pencils

Stickers/papers/ anything you wanted to use in your journal

No perfumes please we have members with allergies.

Albert

results.description:
Our next meeting will be Tuesday, September 8 at 6PM.

Come with your best information to help other to get better or come with your questions on the best way to recover from Fibromyalgia.

If you are new to the group we are very proactive and always striving to get to the core issues of our brain, metabolic and immune dysfunctions. There is so much good information out there (treatments, tools and techniques) that can get us on our way to a better life.

I WILL BE REPORTING ON MY PROGRESS (AND THAT OF 5 OTHERS IN MY ARIZONA SUPPORT GROUP) RELATIVE TO IASIS NEUROFEEDBACK. IT'S A RELATIVELY NEW TREATMENT BASED ON OLDER NEUROFEEDBACK TECHNOLOGY BUT A STEP AHEAD BECAUSE THERE IS NO PLATEAUING OF SYMPTOMS AND RESULTS ARE ENDURING FOR THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS USING IT. I know two people who had severe Fibro and after many treatments one of them who was a 10 out of 10 on the pain scale is now at a manageable 3 with no followup treatments. The other person has no symptoms now and is a IASIS technician herself.

I WILL ALSO BE UPDATING EVERYONE ON THE NEW FIBROMYALGIA BLOOD TEST THAT IS NOW AVAILABLE. MEDICARE, AETNA AND OTHER INSURANCE COMPANIES ARE COVERING IT.  FOR THOSE LIKE ME WITH LOUSY OR NO MEDICAL INSURANCE THE TEST IS $749. IT IS LIKELY YOUR SPECIALISTS AND DOCS DON'T EVEN KNOW ABOUT IT BUT IT WAS DEVELOPED BY A DOCTOR FROM LA WHO IS A FIBRO SPECIALIST AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS MEDICAL SCHOOL WAS THE FACILITY USED TO CREATE IT. This test is based on a unique immune system protein/cytokine that is unique to Fibro folks.

Can't wait to see many of you.

Please bring your donations so I can cover the Meetup.com costs.

I will be back in November for Thanksgiving and will have another meeting then.

Till the 8th, BETSY
results.how_to_find_us: Right off Reading Square on Pleasant Street, can see it from CVS!
results.name: Have a Fibromyalgia meeting

results.description:
AGENDA:

Moderator:  Greg Woolf (CEO, Coalesce)

“Overview: Real Life Examples of Cognitive”

Greg Woolf is the founder of Coalesce, an IBM Watson Ecosystem partner that provides intelligent software for investment research.  Greg took over as moderator of the Cognitive Computing Group in May and is leading the series on “Cognitive Computing in Real Life” and how benefits people today and in the future. (http://www.coalesce.info)

Presenter 1:  Michael Fahey (President and CEO, InfoStorSec)

“Predicting Sudden Cardiac Arrest using Cognitive Computing”

The presentation will cover how Cognitive computing is helping to predict Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA).  This will include a brief explanation of basic heart function, what SCA is, and how it compares to other heart maladies. 

Mike Fahey will cover a history of attempts to predict SCA and their failings, new techniques that leverage cognitive computing to improve SCA prediction, plus the potential impact on healthcare reimbursement.

Presenter 2:  Cara Samia (Product Development Director, Best Doctors)

“Instant online access to reliable answers about medical conditions”

72% of internet users look online for health information. There are significant concerns with online health information’s reliability, validity, availability and accuracy. People still want to speak with a trusted resource – their physician. The problem is time and accessibility. Patients will often have to wait a few days to receive their specific answer. 

Cara Samia will review how the Asklepius product powered by IBM Watson aims to provide Best Doctors Members with instant access to reliable answers about their medical conditions.”
results.name: "Real Life Examples of Cognitive in Health Care"

results.description:
Hi everyone,

After taking the summer to rest and relax, we'll start our monthly meetings again - 2nd Tuesday of each month. So we will meet on Tuesday, Sept. 8. We'll start by getting to know each other and hear a little about plans for the group this year. New members are welcome at any meeting!

The topic for this meeting will be Diagnosing Fibromyalgia. We'll review the old 1990 criteria and the new 2010 criteria. How did you get diagnosed? How long did it take? Do you even get a definite diagnosis? Did that help? Does it matter? We'll share experiences.

Also, since fibromyalgia often overlaps with ME/CFS (also known as Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, ME, or CFIDS) we'll talk a little about what symptoms these two illnesses share. 

Looking forward to seeing everyone!

Charmian

results.description:
Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

How to find us: http://p.irateship.com/treasuremap.html

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.
