It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
Contact: Roberta Dehman Hershon
Telephone: [masked]
September 9th

Going, Going……. Almost Gone: “When Giants Fall”
The Elephant Poaching Crisis
Discussion and Benefit Screening

Every 15 minutes, a wild elephant dies by human hands. Those hands belong to poachers. Poachers involved in the illegal ivory trade. These gentle giants will go the way of the Black Rhino if we do not step in NOW to stop the senseless killing, trafficking and demand for ivory.

The statistics are clear: In 1979 there were 1.3 million elephants roaming free. Today, that number has dwindled to fewer than 400,000. 35,000 African and Asian elephants were slain last year. Another 35,000 will lose their lives in 2015.

According to The International Fund for Animal Welfare, Boston is the fourth largest market for ivory jewelry and trinkets in the United States.

On September 9 at 8:30 p.m. join the people behind the Global March For Elephants Rhinos (GMFER) at the Massachusetts’ documentary preview of When Giants Fall and learn what YOU can do to stop these horrific acts.


CinemaSalem, 1 East India Square Mall, Salem, MA 

Preceding the film, Senator Jason Lewis and Representative Lori Ehrlich, authors of legislation to prevent ivory and rhino horn trafficking in MA along with Tom Lang, co-owner of Alexander Westerhoff Antiques, will lead a panel discussion at 6:30 p.m. 
SalemFive Community Room
210 Essex Street
Downtown Salem, MA 01970

Tickets for both events are $25.00. 
Screening alone: $10; 
Panel discussion alone: $15. 
RSVP required. 
Email [masked]. 
Boston GMFER is an all-volunteer organization that supports education, advocacy and financial assistance for elephant/rhino anti-poaching organizations.
results.name: The Elephant Poaching Crisis Discussion and Benefit Screening

Did you ever imagine speaking could be fun?

Our last Meet-ups won rave reviews from first-time guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]

results.description:
This is the first of several scheduled classes, so sign up only if you can attend the dates and times listed here. 


We will meet 5 times at $5 per person per lesson.  Let's plan to get to Panera between 6 and 6:30 to eat;  then we can tackle the lessons with a satisfied tummy.   The lesson will begin at 7:00 for 5 consecutive Wednesdays (September 9 - October 7).   In the first weeks,  I'll teach basic stitches and we can talk about realistic first projects.  The final weeks will focus on getting you working on your own project. 


I will collect the full amount ($25) at the first lesson so I don't have to bother with collecting  each week and  I prefer cash so I don't have to go to the bank.

You will need a crochet hook in size H, I, or J and a skein of inexpensive "worsted weight" acrylic yarn in a solid, light color for the first class. In the same strip mall as Panera, there is a Michaels craft store where you can purchase these items when we meet on 9/9.  Or you can go to a JoAnn's or AC Moore store.  If you google these stores,  you can probably find a coupon on their sites which will offer a discount off the full price and each store honors coupons from the others.     

There will be homework. 

I will assign a small amount of homework intended to be completed over 3-4 days during the week intended to reinforce what you have learned that week. 


Please be considerate

There is a long list of women who are interested in learning to crochet.  If you RSVP,  please be sure you can attend.  Same day cancellations and no shows will not be tolerated.   You'll be marked as a no show and I won't be willing to include you in a future class.  


If you have any questions,  please send me a message.  I won't necessarily be monitoring this site.

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.name: Study 1 Corinthians

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Urinary tract infections are uncomfortable, irritating – and all-too-often a persistent, recurring problem. Conventional treatment relies on a course of antibiotics, but with the rise of drug-resistant bacteria this approach has two major flaws: first, the antibiotics may be ineffective at eliminating the pathogen (while still quite effective at disrupting your gut flora – making you more susceptible to future infections); and second, even if they do work, continued use will only lead to more resilient bugs in circulation.

Herbs offer an alternative. Their mechanisms of action are varied: some prevent adherence of the bacteria to the walls of the urinary tract, some disrupt the biofilms bacteria form to protect themselves, some kill the invading pathogens directly, and many simply improve the health of the affected tissues to the point that they can fight off infection under their own power.

We’ll introduce you to a variety of useful herbs in this class, and show you how to prepare and administer them for best effect – in tea, tincture, sitz bath, and more. (Men, don’t think you’ll be left out – we’ll make sure to cover expressions of UTI in male anatomy, as well as everyone’s favorite herbal therapy: a good old-fashioned penis soak.)

Wednesday, September 9th, 2015
7:00 – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.
RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Handle it Herbally: UTI

results.description:
Welcome to our regular meetup!  We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing board games -- specifically, the kind of board games that make you think.  We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.

This season, in addition to playing games, we will be raffling off a bunch of popular games!  There will be raffles at each meetup. Simply by showing up, you'll get a chance to win free games. The more often you come, the more entries you'll receive.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message ahead of time, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm until 11:00 pm or later.

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 30-45 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

People new to Euros are very welcome.  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); the heaviest strategy games (like 18xx or wargames); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Carcassonne.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (You will also receive extra raffle tickets any time you donate.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

7:00pm EDT September 9

All Films are open to the public and are free of charge Expert commentary starts at 6:30 p.m. and the film begins at 7:00 p.m. Rogers Center for the Arts
http://www.merrimack.edu/community/rogers/tambakos_programs/

Classic Film

1973 Directed by George Lucas

Starring: Richard Dreyfuss, Ron Howard, Paul Le Mat, Cindy Williams, Harrison Ford, Suzanne Somers, Mackenzie Phillips


It’s the last night of summer 1962, and the teenagers of Modesto, California, wan to have some fun before adult responsibilities close in. Among them are Steve and Curt, college-bound with mixed feelings about leaving home; nerdy Terry “The Toad,” who scores a dream date with blonde Debbie; and John, a 22-year-old drag racer who wonders how much longer he can stay champion and how he got stuck with 13-year-old Carol in his deuce coupe. As D.J. Wolfman Jack spins 41 vintage tunes on the radio throughout the night, Steve ponders a future with girlfriend Laurie, Curt chases a mystery blonde, Terry tries to act cool, and Paul prepares for a race against Bob Falfa. But nothing can stop the next day from coming, and with it the vastly different future ushered in by the 1960s.

Rated PG. 110 mins.

results.description:
Remember when life was simple? When a snow day was a perfect excuse to have fun, not a block of time when you felt guilty about being unproductive. When the ice cream truck could make your day, no matter what happened before. Skinned knee—who cares, you had a blast riding that bike!

Have you ever wondered why now as an adult you keep repeating the same old patterns in your life like failed relationships, issues with money, and feelings out of control? Could it be stemming from your childhood?

Yes, most of these old patterns come from your childhood.

When we were 3 or 4 we couldn't look around us and say, "Well, Dad's a drunk and Mom is real depressed and scared - that is why it feels so awful here.  I think I'll go get my own apartment."

We looked up to our parents, literally. They were your higher power and we were not capable of understanding that they might have problems that had nothing to do with us.  So it felt like it was our fault and many of our limiting beliefs were formed. We learned about love, money and emotions from people who were not capable of loving in a healthy way because of their unhealed childhood wounds.

If only you could bottle that sense of freedom, fun, and enthusiasm for the little things, you could carry it in your responsible adult pocket and take a swig when you started taking everything too seriously. Now you can

Join me as we reconnect to the Child Within.

We will:

Open a dialog with our inner child

Learn & Play

Be Silly & Laugh

Imagine, Create & Draw

And most of all we will Reconnect to Love our Inner Self

results.description:
Join Buzzy Jackson for a talk about her new book THE INSPIRATIONAL ATHEIST: Wise Words on the Wonder and Meaning of Life. 

Atheists are as interested as any believer in making sense of life’s Big Questions – they just don’t look to divine guidance for help. Buzzy Jackson, award winning author of A Bad Woman Feeling Good hopes to remedy that with her self-proclaimed “Chicken Soup for the Soulless”.

Atheism is a rapidly growing movement: as of 2012, one-fifth of the American public claims no religious affiliation at all, but that doesn’t mean they don’t need a little inspiration now and then. 

More and more people are drawn to the secular worldview, because of the intellectual freedom and the moral responsibilities it demands: atheists strive to live ethically because it is the right thing to do. As Katharine Hepburn said, “I believe there’s nothing we can know except that we should be kind to each other and do what we can for people.” 

A trove of wisdom from some of history’s most profound and uplifting artists, poets, philosophers, comedians and great thinkers, Jackson quotes E.B. White, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Epicurus, Oscar Wilde, Julia Child, Leonardo Da Vinci, Albert Einstein, Tina Fey, Zora Neale Hurston, and George Carlin, among many others. THE INSPIRATIONAL ATHEIST spans the ages and is organized into sections devoted to topics such as Morality, Relationships, Happiness, Beauty and Belief. 

THE INSPIRATIONAL ATHEIST is sure to become a treasured daily companion for the growing demographic of humanists, atheists, skeptics, agnostics, and the ‘spiritual-but-not-religious’ among us who trust that life has meaning when we live it meaningfully, with insight that will touch nonbelievers and believers alike 

Buzzy Jackson is the award-winning author of "Shaking the Family Tree: Blue Blood, Black Sheep, and Other Obsessions of an Accidental Genealogist" (Simon & Schuster: 2010) and "A Bad Woman Feeling Good: Blues and the Women Who Sing Them" (W.W. Norton: 2005), She has a PhD in History from UC Berkeley and is a Correspondent for the Boston Globe. Buzzy lives in Colorado with her family and a freethinking dog named Ralph. 

General Information

Our First Wednesday Dialog series brings in outside speakers to share interesting topics related to Humanism -- in the spirit of a Ted Talk. We socialize and enjoy refreshments until about 7:15, at which point the speakers presents for as long as they choose, usually until 8:00 or so. At this point we pass the mic around and have a group discussion about the topic. When the discussion wraps up, we continue with more refreshments and socializing until around 9:00 when all attendees are welcome to join our open steering committee meeting.

We  take donations at the door to cover the cost of the meeting ($5 is suggested). Half of the donations (after we pay the rent) are given as an honorarium to the speaker. For this meeting, Buzzy has specified that her portion will be going to Doctors Without Borders. All regular attendees are encouraged to bring refreshments to share.

Note that we have a large mailing list outside of Meetup.com so the RSVP numbers are generally much lower than the actual attendance.
results.how_to_find_us: The entrance to the Hall is around to the right side if you are facing the Meeting House front doors.
results.name: Buzzy Jackson, "The Inspirational Atheist", First Wednesday Dialog

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Though this event officially begins at 7 PM, people typically begin filtering in around 6:30, which is an opportunity to play a short warm-up game, grab a bite to eat, socialize, or get a jump start if you've arranged with people to start in on a longer game.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we meet to discuss Chapters 19 & 20 of Keynes' "General Theory", as well as Chapters 19 & 20 of Hazlitt's line-by-line critique of "Failure of the New Economics." The readings are not required to attend our meeting, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

READINGS:

"The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money"
by J.M. Keynes
Chapters 19 & 20
http://bit.ly/1QDOIeY

"The Failure of the New Economics"
by Henry Hazlitt
Chapters 19 & 20
http://bit.ly/1RKJIZk

STUDY QUESTIONS:


1) According to Keynes, a reduction in money-wages creates which phenomenon? 


2) Professor Pigou’s “Theory of Unemployment” depends on which two factors? 

3) According to Keynes, can labor determine its real wage? 


4) According to Keynes, which labor phenomenon occurs when the effective demand is deficient? 


5) According to Hazlitt, which phenomenon is a result of free competition among workpeople and a mobile labor force? 


6) According to Hazlitt, Keynes is dismissive of which market, and for what reason? 

7) According to Hazlitt, why are changes in hourly earnings greater than hourly wage-rates? 


8) According to Hazlitt, what is money’s most significant attribute, and which role does it play in economic life?
results.name: UNEMPLOYMENT AND WAGE-RATES

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for Intermediate/Advanced Intermediate level players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike. If you'd like to play, please do the following: Click RSVP or send an email to Click RSVP or send an email to Max using the following URL:

http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=89868512


Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters, and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well. The location for this volleyball meetup is at the JCC of the North Shore, 4 Community Road, Marblehead, MA[masked] | Home Page:

http://www.jccns.org/adult-volleyball/

This event is free if you are a member of JCC. If not, it's a one-time $10 membership fee that is valid for a day. As always, please remember: - Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP) - If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join. Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
RoLa Languages Institute is planning to have a great time with all those who have an interest in speaking English. There will be other English students as well as a native speaker to practice with.

For whom?

Everyone who has any interest in English, from beginner students to native speakers.


When?

Wednesday, September 9th from 7:30 pm - 10:00 pm


Where?

Pho House, 1790 Massachusetts Avenue (above RoLa's Porter Square office in Cambridge)


What will we do?

We will speak English and have some drinks and food!


Come and join our party! We don't care about who you are, where you're from or how you look! Just come and practice your English! This is a really great chance to improve your English skills! 

It's a free, public event but food and drink purchases are a courteous gesture to the restaurant that hosts us, not to mention delicious! 

If you need more information, please contact us!

Website: www.rolalang.com

Email: [masked]

Telephone: (617) 297 - 7789

We hope to see you on Wednesday, September 9th!

results.description:
We will discuss a book on the First Wednesday of every month.  Members will bring a book selection to the meeting, and the members present at the meeting will vote on the books.  We are trying different ways of choosing books and we are open to suggestions.


We are asking members who RSVP to provide the name of a book they would like to read.  I will bring the list to each meeting.

One thing we have noticed is that when voting is done online - through a poll, there is an unfair balance of how many are vote verses who is present to discuss the book.

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: The field is right next to Alewife station on the Red Line. There is also plenty of parking provided no one else is using the field. (Not an issue in the winter.)

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
